description: I always grab a cup of coffee for the ride home here but today for the first time I grabbed a sandwich too. It was excellent! Veggie, with three kinds of cheese, peppers, lettuce and tomato on a fantastic French roll.
author: Adrian C.

description: Had a good BLT and hot tea right near Ocean Beach. Just what I needed.
author: Craig D.

description: I really like this place a lot. The employees are super friendly and nice, and they even help pick out drinks that you might like if you're indecisive (like me). I got the hot chocolate the last time I came here. It was so good; definitely hit the spot that night.
author: Leslie C.

description:
LOVE going to this place.   Really great location, friendly staff, tasty muffins and the coffee is usually above average.   Sometimes takes a bit long, but usually worth the wait.

Always look forward to going to Java Beach!
author: Blake S.

description: Nice seating outside.  Music inside.  Really yummy hot chocolate
author: Miles F.

description: Had an amazing sandwich here. It seemed kind of expensive at first but when you looked at the contents it was a good deal. I don't remember the name but it had lots of turkey, generous pesto on both sides, good amount of cheese, and lots of greens. Decaf coffee was great. Outdoor seating was cozy. I could totally see me and a group of friends meeting here on a regular basis for drinks, well, if I lived closer. :o(
author: Megan S.

description:
i love their salads, oatmeal, and coffee. super tasty. 

the service can be hit or miss and the sandwiches are okay. 

5 stars for the coffee and ambiance, 3 stars for service and sandys, so im averaging them at a 4.
author: Hello G.

description: I live around the corner and have only gone here for coffee a hand full of times.  It is sooo pricey.  The shakes, food, and even the coffee are decent but way too expensive.  You get the feeling you are paying for someone else's lunch.
author: Pat Z.

description: They were super busy yesterday afternoon, but still friendly and effecient.  My pastrami on dutch crunch rocked and I love all the hot pepper toppings for samdwiches and the crunchy, fresh chips were so good.  I was super coveting the coffee milkshake looking thing that the girl next to me was sipping on.  Must peruse the menu more next to to find and devour it.
author: Mac M.

description:
I first visited Java Beach when I was visiting some relatives back in 2004. THIS is the ULTIMATE coffee shop.  It is quirky, charming and a bit divy...which makes for a character and charm rarely found these days in which business's seem to thrive on "franchise sameness".

The staff is friendly and helpful and the selection of sandwiches and snacks are plentiful.  Now...the coffee....REAL COFFEE!!  Organic and fair trade to boot!  Order the DEPTH CHARGE.....it is so wonderful and guaranteed to make your cells vibrate.

I understand about some of you who live and die for Starbucks or Peets, but the coffee at Java Beach IS INCREDIBLE and reminds of my days in Boston at a place called the Cafe Bouquet, directly across the street from the Berklee College of Music and next to TC's Pub.  Coffee served up strong and fresh in a slightly bohemian, but very friendly environment.

My advice: Go to Java Beach, and order something...anything.  Hang out inside for a few to enjoy the very cool vibe.  Then go outside on the patio, grab a seat and people watch.  End the journey with a walk across the street and onto the beach and enjoy that wonderful creation....the Pacific Ocean.
author: Michael G.

description: I love this place for the location - it is a very easy spot to meet friends before heading to the beach.  The staff and ambiance seem fine - I've never had a problem, but haven't had my socks knocked off either.  I've had tea, coffee, and lil sandwiches and things - and they've all been fine.  Just straight up food - gets the job done but nothing to rave about.  I DO love that they are a mom 'n pop joint, tho, and will probably continue to come here unless something happens to change my mind.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
The longer the span of time between visits, the more likely I am to want to throw 5 stars at Java Beach--primarily due to the beautiful location.  But then I go there and realize why it's not as perfect as my mythical vision of it.

I openly recognize that my judgment of coffee shops/cafes is skewed by my devotion to my favorite (Naked Lounge in Chico, CA) and my ongoing quest to find an adequate replacement.  I simultaneously like that this is a bustling business but hate having to wait 10+ minutes for available indoor seating sometimes.  I like that it is cheery and full of conversation sometimes, but not when I come there with my laptop in hopes of busting out a few pages of a research paper.  I like that they serve beer but don't want any bar atmosphere there.  Obviously, these things are not their fault, but they do take away from the experience and make me not as jazzed to visit.

Like others have said, I too have worked in food service for years so I know that the job can often suck big ones.  Most of their employees seem to be generally nice but super jaded, and talk in a I'm-being-cordial-but-I-really-don't-care-about-you way.  On my most recent visit, a few off-the-clock employees were there drinking and being loouuuuuud.

I wish they had more options for small, cheap food items, although the hot veggie and cheese sandwich is a good deal at $5.50 and was quite substantial and yummy.  The only way I'd probably ever purchase one of the $7+ cold sandwiches would be with the intention of taking half home. Half sandwiches! Por favor!
author: Alys D.

description:
I never ventured over here until recently and was able to try the mocha!!!

And it was excellent I loved the the vibe of the cafe, and all the options everything from coffe to beer, and sandwiches and breakfast!!! 

And the bonus is not only do they open early, but they stay open farely late!!!
And parking has never been a problem here!

I will defiently be back!!! Maybe for an energizer before adventuring the zoo across the street!!
author: Noelle L.

description:
Wow, it's always packed but: they actually put real meat on the sandwiches; the free internet works; unlimited coffee (multiple types); relatively easy parking on the street; close to the beach; the REAL sandwich was less than$7.

Anyways, it's a cool place that has its stuff together.  Will return for sure.
author: John A.

description: 2 stars for location only. Waited over 30 minutes for a sandwich (cold not even hot) Crazy busy in there also.
author: Christopher D. L.

description:
Wow.

Let's just say this: I'm pretty happy that I chose this place to hang out with my friend -- THANK YOU YELP. We had walked all the way from Golden Gate Park and were about to digest ourselves when we found this place. It's located just at Judah and the Great Highway, right near the muni.

The prices were pretty standard -- came out to about 22$ for the two of us for drinks and lunch. The coffee, on both our parts, was amazing. They serve up to four shots in your drink (should you be crazy enough to want that) and their iced coffee was strong and tasty, not watery like other places. They made a mistake by making my friend's mocha hot, but efficiently and graciously put it on us for us (it was MELTING today).

The Sandwiches, about 7.25$ if I remember correctly, were massive and delicious. I ordered the vegetarian (offered hot and cold..guess which I picked?) and it came with fresh tomato, onion, avocado, sprouts, and three cheese on dutch crunch. yummm.

The atmosphere is great, definitely an SF-locals-type hangout, with nice people all around. A little crowded but not noisy. My one gripe is that the bathrooms were a little dirty and they were out of handsoap (especially when you're going to eat a sandwich). 

But seriously-- with all the great reviews, take a beach day! JUST TRY IT! You won't regret it. :)
author: Asaf K.

description:
post morning beach run and you've restored my hope that i CAN find an almost-decent bagel west of the Berkshires. 

come here when it's sunny, get your sandwich and stay awhile"
author: Angelina C.

description:
Java Beach is the kind of awesome little local spot that makes me not totally regret living in the Outer Sunset. On those rare, warm, sunny days, I slap on my flip-flops, grab my iPod, and head for a nice walk over to Ocean Beach. I complete my journey with a hot veggie sandwich (with the works), and an iced tea for the way back. 

The hot veggie is deeelicious. I've never been a big fan of the hot sandwich, or of peppers on my sandwich, but oh man, I freakin' love this sandwich. Some days, a girl just doesn't want to cook (okay, most days), and so I'll head over here.

The coffee and tea are pretty decent (yay for fair trade and organic). I love that they have simple syrup in addition to the standard sugar and cream at the coffee bar--makes sweetening my iced lattes a helluva lot easier. 

It's a great place to people watch. People wander in after a day at the beach, to study or work, after walking the dog, to catch up with some friends, and so on. The staff are friendly, and everyone who goes there just seems like they're in a good mood. Basically, this is just a nice, chill place to relax with a good friend over a beer or latte. But you probably already knew that.
author: Erin M.

description: The Mexican salad was super delicious, i love the atmosphere, it is cute and totally Southern California surfer style!
author: Jasmine F.

description:
My friend took me here for lunch. The sandwiches were amazing. They have a really good selection of sandwiches: hot and cold. You can also build your own sandwich as well.  I got the veggie sandwich (cucumbers, avocado, lettuce, onion, three types of cheese of your choice, and mustard) on ciabata bread. My friend's hot pastrami sandwich also looked really good.  I also got an italian soda, which I thought was way too syrupy, so I could not finish. Next time i will try the coffee, which I heard they are known for. 

Overall, if you are looking for a fast place for sandwiches or a good coffee shop in this area, this is a great place for you.
author: Mai L.

description:
Maybe I was a bit unfair with that 2-star review.  Yesterday, I was hanging out at Ocean Beach with two girls I met on the N-Judah, one of who recognized me from a Super Bowl Party thrown by my former co-worker in North Beach.   They were enjoying the day on the sand, catching up, and I quickly excused myself and went into Java Beach to get a quick cup of coffee.

My eyes were averted from the super-connected laptop patrons.

Surprise surprise, I was happy to get a medium Dark French Roast coffee with fast and friendly service, and I barely glanced at the other patrons.

For a quick coffee to-go, why not Java Beach?  For sit down coffee with a friend, I'll still go somewhere else.  STILL WAY TOO MANY FOLKS ON LAPTOPS HERE!  ON A BEAUTIFUL SUNNY BEACH DAY!

This would be the opposite of what French people would call a "douce ambiance".
author: Justin C.

description:
Ok, 1 star for the food/drinks and 1 star for its location. 
  On my sandwich I asked for no onions, cucumbers, or sprouts. I even repeated it to make sure the guy got it. I got all 3 on my sandwich. I'm very used to getting onions on my sandwich when I ask for none, but I'm not one to complain. The sandwich I received here was very tasty, after having to remove all three ingredients I didn't want. The thing that irks me about that is, what if I was allergic to one of those ingredients? You can't just mess up like that. 
  It's location is gorgeous, especially on nice days when you can pick something up and walk straight to the beach. 
  I feel like the people here are a lot colder than the ones at the Sloat Java Beach. They aren't rude, just not very people-friendly. I understand they're busy, but there's no excuse for being cold with your customers. When I first walked in, an employee came up behind me and said "Excuse me." Again, the only word I can use to describe the way she said it, is coldly.
   I felt like I was intruding on them. I work in a cafe and the last thing I want to do is upset my customers or make them feel uncomfortable. 
  So I wouldn't say to avoid this place... if you're near it then go for it. But I would just get what you want (after making sure it IS what you want) and leave. I wouldn't hang around.
author: Giovanna C.

description:
Nice place to get a $9.oo sandwich. 
The coffee is local, and good. skip the food just get the coffee of the day.
author: Valerie B.

description: Great coffee, very slow service. Took 10 minutes to make a latte, and they weren't even busy
author: Garry P.

description: some folks are complaining that JAVA BEACH CAFE is 'crazy busy'...what???.. like that is a bad thing?
author: Addadada A.

description: I collected all the chaos of my day and brought myself to finally try this place! So glad I did! It was a beautiful day out, so I enjoyed my Acai bowl on one of the tables outside. I know what a good Acai bowl tastes like, and this one was pretty good.. especially because I went months without having one before I came here.
author: Milli F.

description:
Sure it's at the end of the line and that's convenient.
Sure it's always packed (because it's so cold outside you need tea to warm you up).
Sure you can never find a place to seat ('cause everyone and their laptops).
Sure it's popular (well, it's the only one --- duh).
And sure, it's close to me, but I never go, and here's why:

Whenever I go near this coffee shop, I feel like I am in Santa Cruz. The chicks with flip-flops stand-out. I always feel like telling them how the water isn't warm or ask if they forgot their socks.

Their coffee is---flavor-less. Messy. Dirty cups.
Their food is expensive and you gotta be specific about what you want in it. If you order a Cesar salad, be sure to let them know to add greens, cheese, ranch, and chicken. Otherwise you might only get 2 ingredients. Imagine being stuck with ranch and cheese? Oh no!

Sandwiches are um---did I use the word flavor-less already? Damn.

One time I saw a lady solving crossroad puzzles while drinking beer. I couldn't help but think how pathetic that was.
author: Alexia R.

description: A nice beach bum sophisticated ambiance with delicious food, treats and beverages. I love the Java Ice Tea.
author: Chantal L.

description:
It gets crowded for a reason.  I love the hot vegi sandwich.  The yerba matte tea is the best.  The calm environment and sweet staff is a big draw for me.  Plus it's near my house and right by the beach.  I love this place. 
 It's a good place to be on a cold day.
author: amanda v.

description:
Java Beach brings a cool little vibe to the Ocean Beach Sunset area. Its located right on the corner at the end of the N line. Occasionally you can get in here and there are just a few people and plenty of prime seating. But most of the time the place is packed, which is good. 

They have a decent sized patio to sit on if you dare, considering it usually doesn't peak 68 degrees down here. The inside has a cute little bar top you can sit at in front of their 6 or so beers on tap. Also some couch room and table and chairs. 

On the weekends you can usually find some kind of live music which is cool and fun. Oh did i mention FREE WIFI?? That fact alone may add an hour to my stay there. Very friendly staff, not so quick of service. But thats what you get when the food is very fresh. They have soup, sandwiches, salads, breakfast items, and assorted baked goods, and lots of good coffee.

Because a lot of tourist roll through here it can get a little cluttered and dirty. People don't understand the concept of cleaning up after themselves. 

All around a cool quaint quirky little place in the Sunset. It is especially nice later on because its mostly locals hanging out down there. They are open from 5am-11pm everyday i think.
author: theresa b.

description:
Java Beach ... I've only heard good remarks from friends about the place and wanted to check it for myself. 

There's plenty of seating t for everyone: chairs with tables, outside seating, couches with side tables and coffee tables. ATM and Free WiFi. Service was good though I'm sure even better for the regulars almost obligatory for successful coffee shops.  

The place has full menu of cafe drinks accompanied with sandwihces, salads and tea.
 
I ordered a small (10 oz) Chai Tea w/ Honey Soy for $3.90. A bit on the pricey side for me but sticker shock quickly disappeared cause the drink was nothing short of perfect. Smooth, sweet, and light! 

I just watched someone order a pitcher of beer from the tap, it's 10am! It's only the first of many repeat visits by me...I'm a fan!
author: simon l.

description: Love the non-dairy options: soy, almond, and rice milk!
author: waiming B.

description:
I think sometimes places get better ratings because of their decor/location. Java beach definitely is one of those places. On a sunny, mildly breezy day, sitting at a table outside just FEELS GOOD. The inside is kind of surf bum nice which adds to the laid back feeling you get walking in. 

Why the two stars though? I'd give it 2.5 if I could...just for the ambiance. I ordered a small iced mocha and it turns out for iced drinks they only do large and jumbo sized. Anyway, turns out I wound up paying about $4 for what really amounted to a big cup of chocolate milk. Had to wind up throwing it away! For their sake, I hope their other coffee drinks and sandwiches are better.
author: Chris D.

description: spent $14 on a roast beef sandwhich on old bread, little to no mayo, lettuce that tasted like cardboard and honestly, a pissed off customer that spends $14 on a sandwhich that tastes like the meat was from a package. 4 for an iced latte that tasted like feet. i shall never return.
author: Jossy W.

description:
After reading the glowing reviews - I decided to head over on one of SF's rare sunny days.

1st thoughts: This place is cute!! It reminds me of summers at the beach in Venice, CA. Laid back, dudes in shorts and tshirts, and the smell of the salty ocean mixing with the coffee and food. Wonderful. 

2nd thoughts: It's pretty crowded by the food/coffee pickup area. Is that a hooker that just walked in? 

Final thoughts: Seemed like the pimp got the hooker her coffee so alls good. My granola bowl was delicious! Each bite had a fresh, succulent, fruity surprise mixed with honey and yogurt. The mocha had a bit too much chocolate - but the girls behind the counter were handling the rush like pros! I want to sample their juicy looking sammies and cinnamon toast. 

This will be my go to spot on beach days or whenever I need to relax and catch up on my work.
author: Laura R.

description: Good vegan sandwich and vegan chocolate chip cookie.  Outdoor seating is nice but can be a bit crowded.  Coffee drinks are good.  Nice to grab your drinks and walk across the street to enjoy the beach.
author: K W.

description: Super solid beach cafe. Bagels, coffee, chai, tea, salads, sandwiches, oatmeal, granola - this spot has just about everything. The quality isn't amazing but is far from bad. I had the granola, fruit, yogurt bowl with an English Breakfast. The granola was crunchy and laced with honey. The yogurt was rich and thick. The fruit was blueberries, honeydew, cantaloupe and pineapple. I was totally impressed. The crowd is a total mix from beach bums, tourists, neighborhood locales and cops.
author: Catherine C.

description:
Who first introduced me to this place? Maybe it was one friend who grew up in Santa Cruz and is really into coffee and the NorCal vibe. Maybe it was another friend who's into finding down home places full of healthful food but devoid of pretension. Maybe it was the free-spirited 19-year-old girl who worked with me behind the counter of a burger shop where I worked for four months to make rent and live with my sister for five great months before I had to go down South (boo) for grad school. Maybe I found it myself when I hopped the N-train without paying and took it to the end of the line or hoofed the 1.3 miles downhill to the great wide sea. 

Since then, though, I've gone back so many times alone or with friends and family, always to feast on one of the large (approximately foot long) hot subs, aburst with a pile of paper thin meats welded to juicy tomatoes and crispy shredded lettuce by the cheese of your choice (pepper jack is a wise choice), all pressed smartly between yielding but crunchy-fresh flour-dusted French roll bread ("the works," sprouts, and avocado are a must). On the days that I was foolish enough to have eaten without anticipating a visit here, I settled for a Muddy Waters or a plain old Americano, cheerfully shoving aside shells of The Guardian and other partial newspapers to grab one of the couch seats or opting to feel the chill ocean breeze misting through every pore of my skin at one of the iron tables outside among bright-eyed starling birds and wolf-like dogs awaiting the return of their owners with thumping tails.

Here, Norcal beach bums, regular bums, sporty people, West Coast yuppies (for they DO differ from East Coast yuppies), Ocean Beach surfers, students, and every walk of life above, below, and in between meld into one another. The inside and outside of this place are always full, but the staff keeps it moving without being nazis to customers. The average wait for a sandwich is about seven minutes, but it goes fast while calmly people watching or eavesdropping on the mellow and/or idealistic conversations happening quietly all around. A short visit to the home-like bathroom or an absentminded survey of the few beers on tap while leaning on the slightly sticky but not disgusting wooded bar counter by the serving station usually helps the time pass, and then the order is hot in your hot chubby little hands. The sandwich is unspeakably delicious when devoured instantly, but also stays hot during another short stolen ride (sorry, MUNI, but it's all a part of the experience, or my experience, anyway) back up the hill from the trusty N-train. 

I didn't write about Java Beach until now because it's so precious and so local that I figured that all the people who deserve to find it somehow will. But a recent revisit to the place got me to decide to stop pretending I can keep it all to myself when the whole vibe is open to all. My mom and I stopped there to kick off an impulse trip to a 10-mile hike at Point Reyes. I ordered a large hot salami sub with all the aforementioned fixins and took a chance on a medium tuna melt without mayo. Knowing Mom was craving breakfast, I threw a mushroom, spinach, and feta croissant pocket in there (toasted, of course). Feeling extra cheeky, I did the unthinkable and ordered a SWEET coffee drink; a small White Mocha with a dollop of whipped cream to boot. The total? $21.95. Trust me, this is cheap. 

The coffee was creamy and sweet, but didn't make me feel like purging after the third sip. It stayed regular throughout. The stuffed croissant was maddeningly tasty and barely lasted until we hit the 101 North. The sandwiches stayed fresh until we reached the very tippity tip and the midpoint of our hike (but obviously lost their heat after a 2 hour drive and a five mile walk over the sea cliffs).

The sub was too salty for my mother's taste, so she politely put it down and snarfed down the melt with chunks of real fish poking through the a bubbly blanket of cheddar. I had a half of both sandwiches, and my sister enjoyed the other half of the sub, after we were long gone back to snow-covered Boston.

I consider Java Beach a local place no matter where the winds take me. When I walk in, the same fresh faced young girls and rugged young men with free attitudes only found in the Bay Area will greet me with apt and sunny regard, representing again and again the "sun" in Outer Sunset. I await the days!!
author: Jia J.

description:
A three and a half hour lunch break, during our first year in law school.  Two chicks.  Warm weather in February.

What to do?  Why, go to the beach and drink a pitcher of beer, of course.  And then text all our friends in - ahem, COLDER CLIMATES - to taunt them mercilessly.

Java Beach is one of my favorite places to take friends, out-of-towners, and the occasional date - if they don't like the laid-back atmosphere and delicious food, they're probably not going to be happy with anything else I can offer.

I especially love the pesto/mozzarella/tomato sandwich, although the basil has a habit of getting stuck in your teeth (note how I blamed the basil, and not myself - mark of a future lawyer).  The coffee is good.  They have good beer on tap, served by the glass or by the pitcher - and come on, why would you want to stop at just one glass?

Prices are fine - not cheap enough to make it an every day treat, but I believe most sandwiches are $5-8.  Beer is $13-18/pitcher.  Coffee is around $2-3.

Best of all, it's a hop, skip, jump, and kick-your-shoes-off-and-roll-your-jeans-up from the beach.
author: Jennie K.

description:
Yeah, Yeah. Per some Yelpers' reviews, this place is loitered by beach bums, college students, surfers, and angry regulars. They are all sprawled out on the few couches while glaring at newbies who just stopped in for a meal. Who cares? They're really harmless.

After moving from San Jose almost a decade ago, this place was my home and taught me a few survival skills about living in San Francisco. I come from the part of San Jose (my family home) where I was taught to say please, thank you, and excuse me if you unintentionally bump into someone. I am thankful to Java Beach for wiping all that nonsense out of my system and skilling me in rude street maneuvers. 

For example, if I bump someone in passing and it's obviously my mistake, I can give you that WTF? STARE like it's your fault. You will say sorry without hesitation. Cool skill, right? I learned that at Java Beach almost a decade ago!

So, if you need to touch up on your rudeness and your tummy is rumbling for a delicious sandwich. Yes, delicious sandwich, then this is your place. 

The warm sandwiches are the best! (sm. $4.25 med. $5.95 large $6.65) 
The bread is absolutely scrumptious. It has that perfected crunch sound when your teeth hits the surface and then sinks into soft delicious goodness. Oh, yeaaahh...that's what I'm talking about. CRUNCH! The ingredients are locally grown and mostly organic

Salads ($5.75-$7.75) - Generous portions of healthy goodness.

Pastries ($1-$3) - Huge soft and flakey pastries.

Coffee - Good enough. All Fair Trade.

BEER ON TAP!

Overall: Great eclectic atmosphere, exquisite bread for delicious sandwiches or not, outdoor seating (dogs invited outdoor), and enough sass to either keep you away or finding your way back for a sandwich. The crowd has gotten softer throughout the years, so you may get smiles instead of intentional glares.
author: Liz K.

description:
A coworker and I had a beer here after work.  
Coffee shops that serve beer automatically get 4 Stars from me regardless of the service, location, food quality, health code violations, ext.  WHATEVER.  They serve BEER.  What else do you want?  Coffee?  A scone? Pft. You people just don't know.
So what I'm trying to say is this place is great to have a beer on a sunny day, as it is located right by the beach with plenty of outside seating!!
They also have excellent service, a delightful array of pastries, cute puppies frolicking around everywhere, and Stella on tap.
Stella on tap.
Stella on tap.
Stella on tap.
OH!  And an extra star for the coffee, which I have sampled before and is in fact quite tasty!  
And I was just informed via a "you're cool" compliment that the sandwiches here are bombastico fantastico!!!!  
(I made that last phrase up.  You like?)
author: Starla D.

description: This is a nice little cafe near the beach.  It is very busy and hard to find a table inside and out!  I was looking for a good place to do some work on my computer and I didn't have any head phones with me so it was a little hard because it's loud as well.  They have a $5 minimum on cc/debit transactions, but I saw no sign that stated this.  She allowed me to make the purchase any how, but next time I know.  Proper signage please!  It wasn't the cleanest but like I said it's a nice little spot near the beach.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
"To exist is to change, to change is to mature, to mature is to go on creating oneself endlessly"--- Henri Bergson, French philosopher.

Even though change is a part of human nature, paradoxically, human nature has a lot of resistance to change. We all need change; change from the monotony of work as well as change from the monotony of monogamy/partners etc. Since our mind seeks "perpetual novelty",   breaking the limiting patterns of "same old;same old" always brings joy to our heart.

One of the few places in SF where I feel really acts as a "change" to my dense urban living is when I ride the 38 to the very end, walk the half mile down Ocean Beach to Java Beach Caf, order a strong coffee and snuggle into the sofa. The environment of surfer dudes and aging hippies transports my mind to Lahaina Beach and the smell of the sea breeze is making my vacation in Maui memorable.

I sip a Stella from the tap and fall into a stupor. Around me, people bask in the lazy glow of sunshine eating sandwiches and drinking coffee while others are being playful with their work courtesy the free wifi. 

The sound of the Pacific Ocean reminds me of the infinite potential of the human spirit. Life is refreshing(maybe the 4 stellas have something to do with it?). I stumble into the N Judah and as I head back to my concrete jungle, I feel that I have become the change  which I seek in the world.
author: Kaustav C.

description:
Ah, the Tsunami sandwich is excellent.  So is their breakfast granola bowl - YUM!!!  As are their assortment of drinks - beers on tap, caffeinated drinks of great variety, and more.  Vibe? Wonderful.  Food? Delicious.  Customer service? Great, personable, cheerful. + + + +

The draw back?  The singletons with their lap tops who paid for a coffee 2-3 hours ago, who are still sitting there taking up an entire table or half the couch, when there is seriously limited seating.  Apparently the Java beach staff sees no need for paying customers, those who just paid 20 bucks for a couple sandwiches and drinks, to have any sort of seating.  They are content to have the free-loading wireless users take up all the space.

Sometimes the line is ridiculously long too.  My recommendation is to call ahead, order your sandwich, then by the time you are to the front of the line it will be ready and you can take it to go.  Sadly, they don't give you chips with your sandwich if you get it to go.
author: Danielle S.

description:
I hope for everyone's sake that the day I was there just happened to be an abnormally miserable day at JB. The employees are slower than the second coming of christ and rude to boot! More interested in chitter-chatter behind the scenes, they were slow to agknowledge my presence and then did their best to make me feel like the most Unwanted Customer Ever by rolling their eyes when I asked a question, sighing loudly when I requested no ice in my tea, and so on and so forth. Almost as polite as pitbulls guarding a junkyard, these folks need a visit from Miss Manners. And then a doctor. To pull whatever is stuck up there out. 
Aside from the heaping helping of nasty, my salad was delicious and my tea was divine. The location is excellent and convenient on my morning jog. Great outdoor seating and free internet inside, too!
author: Autumn K.

description:
Anything that reminds of Southern CA gets 5 stars from me!  

Even though Ocean beach is kinda colder and foggier, the people here have the laid back Southern CA spirit that I love.  Everyone is happy, and nice and friendly and seems to know each other.  

Coffee, sandwiches, snacks and pastries and even beer.  Warm cozy couches, tons of seating!  LOVE THIS PLACE!!!
author: Denise B.

description:
When you get near 300 reviews, I really wonder if you need mine.

This place is insane during a nice weekend, and they are always excited, chipper, friendly, and professional.

The food is great, the fruit bowl is incredible.  

I love this place. 

Sooooooooooo much.  So there.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: A cute cafe right near the beach with friendly staff and great hot and cold drinks.  Plus comfy couches and tables to crash at.
author: Karen F.

description: Java Beach isn't anything extraordinary as a coffee shop.  It's not particularly inviting or cozy, but it's location is perfect, hence the 4 stars.  Passable coffee at the beach is a beautiful thing, so be thankful.
author: Michael D.

description:
I love a cafe where they know how to make Americanos- not dumping the expresso- but  letting it slowly drip into the tilted reservoir- to prevent all that good coffee bean oil from escaping... the result- a fragrant, creme frothed coffee swirling on top... 
Wonderful sandwiches, pastries, teas and BEER...WIFI service too...And for all you sun lovers- the front patio has enough seating and benches to make some Vit. D...
PS- dont forget your SPF lotion and sunglasses- and hoodie- can get pretty windy!
author: Arissa C.

description:
I've been going to Java forever so I am so glad that they have the best hot sub sandwich in SF!  I have been a Sub Center advertisement for as long as I can remember but Java truly has outdone Sub Center on West Portal.  They even know it by advertising their hot sub sandwiches as "There are also our world famous hot sub sandwiches. Unparalleled in size and quality, these hot subs must be experienced to understand." on their website and I can not agree with the statement more.

The bread is perfect, the lettuce shredded, turkey carved, special dressing Italian.  The Large sub w tax is under $7 and it is worth every penny. The carrot cake is to die for as well!  You get free Wi Fi with purchase and if your in the mood for spirits there is a great selection of beers on tap.  This is not your ordinary little coffee shop by the beach.
author: Frankie F.

description:
If the coffee were to my standards, I'd give it a 5 star. But, sadly it is not. I have never been a fan of those "serve yourself" coffee pump canisters.  However, you will be safe with any espresso drink - I usually get a caramel latte - very good. 

If you are looking for a really tasty deli sandwich - Java Beach will satisfy. They have both warm and cold options, but note - you can request "warm" with any. I love their turkey swiss - served warm. The meat is juicy and the roll is perfectly toasted. 

This is also the ideal spot for happy hour (4-7) on a sunny day. You can sit in the sun facing the dunes, share a pitcher of Guinness while watching the surfers cross the street, dog walkers and N-Judah riders get off. There is a median garden park on the street for overflow and also if you want a more tranquil spot to sip your latte or pint.
author: Amy E.

description: I like this place allot good sandwiches and good pastries. Both of my visits were on Sunday morning and both times there was a line, despite the line I hot my sandwich and pastry fast.
author: Oscar A.

description:
Consistant!

I've been coming to Java Beach for I'm thinking 15 years. It seems like a long time so I'll have to check with the owners. Yup, this was before they had beer or oatmeal, or chai. Way before wireless.

I love this place because the staff has pretty much always been consistently cool, or sweet or just nice. The quality of their products and the way they serve them has been consistently great over the past years. Neat, warm and with a smile. 

Although the crowd has changed and I'd say not as diverse as it was in the 90s, it's still fairly friendly - in fact friendlier than in most places. 

Come grab something hot before going to our cool beaches. The coffee, oatmeal and chai are always great (.65 extra for soy can be painful), and the pastry selection is yummy in your tummy - and although it's been awhile, I'll be their turkey sandwich is still the best in town. 

Thank
author: Fresh E.

description:
If surfy acoustic soul-crooner Jack Johnson were to be reincarnated as a coffee shop, it would be this place.

There are always dogs, children and a mellow, contemplative vibe to be found here.

Little known factoid:  Sublime front man Bradley Nowell died in a hotel room just up the street from this joint.  

Situated as it is on the end of the N-Judah line, and mere steps from Ocean Beach, this place seems as though poised on the precipice of civilization.  An island in a glittering sea of nothingness, as it were.

If you come here on a Sunday morning, try one of the sandwiches and the chocolate chip muffin.  They really are tremendous.
author: Gopal R.

description:
I've hit up this place several times since living here in SF, usually to get late night coffee.

Last night a friend of mine was driving back home and wanted some coffee for the drive home so we popped on over to the only coffee place I knew of that was open past 10pm.

We arrived and I've been craving sugar so I asked the woman (with glasses) if they happened to have any chocolate croissants left?  She said I was in luck and handed me my chocolate, buttery sweet.  I joked that I'm on a sugar kick and I didn't care if it was 10:30pm.  She agreed and said "Sure, why not, you deserve it, don't deprive yourself!!"  She cracked me up.

I waited for my tea while I munched on my croissant on one of the empty sofas.  My friend and I just sat and chatted.  A couple groups were in just having wine talking and hanging out.  It looks like they had live music earlier as one the guys at the table was cleaning up his equipment.

They annoyed that the cafe was closing in 7 minutes, but most of us stayed put for a little while.  The cool girl with the glasses started to pick up empty glasses so I took that as the cue that we should head out.  It was after 11pm when we left so it was cool they didn't say "we're closed now" when it hit 11pm.  A cop and other people popped in just before closing for a beer and coffee who were still served.  That's cool.  They could be regulars though who they're cool with hanging out while they clean up the place.

Anyway, I had my sugar fix and my friend got her coffee fix.  Nice folks and super chill if you wanna hang out by the beach at night.  I've been there during the day too which can be super busy, especially on a nice day.  Lots of surfers and beach goers.  Locals with their dogs too.

They have sandwiches, granola stuff, muffins and other pastries and specials of the day for drinks.  My friend had the mint mocha which she said was good.All around nice place to hang out or grab a cup of somethin' somethin' at all hours of the day.
author: imelda j.

description:
i lived a block away from this place. the people are nice and helpful unlike those hipster sons of bitches down the street at trouble. 

if java beach was ever to go to war with trouble. i would proudly serve with java beach. not just because i like them and spent my money and time there but because i hate trouble and every hipster or trying to be hipster who frequents their rude, condescending establishment. 

die trouble, die.

the espresso makers at java beach are on the ball. very good espresso. i miss the espresso. we have moved due to the fear of the infestation of hipsters to the neighborhood. i'm afraid they are much like roaches and i blame those no good bastards and their predator looking leader guilateta or however its spelled to be at fault.

i visit the city, weekly for psychiatric appointments. i make a routine to drive by trouble and scream an obscenity or two while on my way to java beach to get a cappuccino with 4 fucking shots bro.

speaking of shots. i now feel the need to pack heat because of the hipster plague that has engulfed the outer sunset.

fuck you trouble, fuck you.
author: Nathan B.

description:
This place is ok, but the only big problem i have, is when there is any kind of line, it takes forever to make your latte. Even with 5 people working behind the counter this place seems extremeley slow. I have waited more than 30 minutes with less than 10 people waiting for my latte.  Usuually i am in a hurry so i have chosen other coffee joints just for this reason.

Their biggest plus is nice location and beer on tap.
author: Eric H.

description: Great place to begin a stroll down Ocean Beach. Lots of people just hanging out, sipping their tea or coffee, munching on some fantastic pastries or sandwiches. My friend got their hot chocolate with soy milk. The woman actually made it with milk but caught herself before finishing. I just had some of the very strong coffee. Definitely well-made! I'd like to come back and try some of the sandwiches.
author: michael s.

description:
Going to Ocean Beach feels like leaving SF proper and stopping by Java Beach Cafe evokes that same out of town feeling.  It's inevitable that you'll run into surfers but also families, old timers, students and so forth, all of whom are drawn to the relaxed vibe and the availability of street parking.  

The display case is filled with croissant sandwiches, bagels and other pastries.  I haven't tried those but I did have a bowl of oatmeal (hot oatmeal - yum) that I enjoyed (and they have brown sugar if you want it).  The latte was quite good.

Then there's the free wi-fi....which I have no complaints about.  And I don't mind that the tables are close together.  But I do mind the fact that there are no power outlets, making it difficult to hang out here for hours (and be on your laptop).  

They take credit cards but the minimum is $10 or was it $15?
author: Lolia S.

description:
(Okay, I'm rusty. Haven't done one of these in a while so here goes:)

Belly Sam Bitch and Two Key Sam Bitch for Cara!!
Belly Sam Bitch and Two Key Sam Bitch for Cara!!
Followed by that infamous, Mothra screeching piercing sound!
(Ah those Japanese Monster Flicks!)

That about sums up the effect of the woman calling out the orders at Java Beach. Now I'm not making fun of her. It's just that it was pretty busy in there and noisy too! Anyway, I know it's not the woman's fault that her voice was irritating the heck out of my lunch pal (Say Hey Starla!) and yours truly. Anyway, on to Java Beach.

I've been coming here for the past year during my lunch hour with my co-workers. I can't think of a better place to sit down and order food and enjoy those rare sunny warm days by the beach.  The sandwiches here are surprisingly good. I don't know what it is though. Could it be the secret sauce? Starla says it's no secret, I say it's good. I've only had the veggie sandwich which is pretty good. Honestly the sandwiches are rather plain looking. Visually bland would be how I would describe them. You know, run of the mill bread, served on a very generic looking plate.

But I must tip my cap to them because once you take a bite, you forget about the permanent ear damage and nail scratching the chalkboard torture we had to endure just to get our food. The food is good, the coffee is fab and the beer! Did I mention they serve Beer? Sorry Starla, I had to steal your line! Yep, I come here after work, take a walk down the beach and cross the highway to JB for a brew.

My advice, is bring earplugs while you wait for your food. After that just sit down and enjoy. Oh, they tend to be on the slow side in preparing the food but to me it's well worth the wait. Hey, plenty going on here to keep you visually entertained!

Cheers!
author: Mas R.

description: our savior on a cold and windy day at ocean beach.  of course we got some hot drinks but to our surprise they also had beer and wine as well.  looking at folks around i believe they offer free wifi and from what we saw at the counter their deserts and snack items looked good.  great location and a friendly and efficient staff makes me recommend this place.
author: Carlo H.

description:
Java Beach is my hangout. It's a lot of people's hangout. There is reason for this. The reason is that it is awesome.

When I was student I often sought refuge here to eat // study // eat // study the day away. Now that I'm a working stiff, I often WFJB (it's a variation of WFH, but with more food). 

The sandwiches - I recommend a medium salami, heated with the works; fatty goodness.

The coffee - a smorgasbord of freshly brewed coffees to fit your personal fancy. I'm a Bernie's Blend kinda girl. Or if you're in the mood for something a little more frilly, they're espresso drinks are also great. Be adventurous and try a latte with coconut syrup, perfect afternoon treat.

The scene - As I was eating/working/eating here a few months ago, and Gavin Newsom popped in to tape an interview. This should validate the scene-ness of the place and what a community staple it is for those who are unfamiliar.

Another big plus for me as a new mommy, the puppy kind not the baby kind, is how pet friendly this place is. Bringing your dog in to order is no big thing and there is plenty of outside seating for you and your BFF to enjoy beach breeze and free wifi together.

Only thing to beware of is how crowded and noisy the joint can get. If you're coming to be productive and tend to get distracted easily, this is not the place for you. I'm an ear bud addict myself, so the chatter doesn't bother me. Every-buds diff :)
author: Taylor E.

description:
This is my Mocha Please... Before going to the beach for a walk, I get a mocha and head to the ocean! The baristas behind the counter are always nice, even when this place is hoppin at 9 am on a Tuesday! Still, I love the chill vibe and beach vibe of this place, 

I have not tried any of the food-- so no comment on the taste or quality...but it does look good and will on my next visit.

I'll be back!
author: Valerie D.

description:
Super cute place!  

Super cute staff.

Super cute...uh I mean good coffee.

I didn't get any food here but I certainly was tempted.  Next time.
author: desiree n.

description:
A java house along a nice bike route, this place is becoming a regular stop for me on the weekend when the weather is good.  Expect a long long line (although it moves along fairly quickly) with classic beach bums, well-pedicured ladies with their groomed poodles, and everything in between.  

The muffins here are HUGE...  I mean, HUMONGOUS.  I can have it as a meal in and of itself.  The coffee selection... very awesome.. from regular roast to flavored ones (my fave hazelnut among them!)   Steaming hot, and meanly roasted.   Just the way I like it.   I've not had anything else here... but the muffins and coffee are enough for me to come back for more.
author: Shirley F.

description:
It's all about the coffee.

Oh yeah, and they serve beer, sandwiches, muffins, tea, etc. Have free wi-fi and are always open.
author: Christopher B.

description:
The sandwiches here is AMAZING! However, the wait is crazy long. Every time I come here its at least a 30 - 40 minute wait on my sandwich, but its so delicious that its worth it. Plus, its not like i stand around waiting for it to come, I'm normally settling in or doing my homework by the time they announce my order. 

They open pretty late, its right next to the beach, and they offer free internet. This place is definitely one of my favorite cafe in the city :D
author: Tina T.

description: I like this place - great coffee and great sandwiches. Wish they had a time limit for laptop users because there's never a place to sit.
author: Bill W.

description:
This is the perfect neighborhood coffee spot.  Nice people, cozy place, everything you could want from a coffee house and more.

Coffee and a hot ham-n-cheese croissant and I'm happy.

My only complaint is the price.  I'm not saying that it's wrong, I just wish it was a notch less.  But that's what I get for living in SF.
author: J K.

description:
Highlights: Java Beach has a great atmosphere and the sandwiches are good. I had the cheese, tomato, and pesto--great! 

Suggestion: I would consider changing the refill policy. This place has a steady flow of clientele there no need to charge full price for refills.
author: Jose R.

description: great tea as well as coffee. Perfect for a sandwich that will satisfy too.  Friendly and sweet staff. If your down in this area stopin. You will be made feel comfortable.
author: Debi C.

description:
It's certainly true that the beach gives this a sort of SoCal (or at least Central Coast) vibe.  But don't worry, it's still a good place:)

Actually, while the tourists head to the Cliff House and, to a lesser extent, the Beach Chalet, the locals know this is the real beach place to hit.  Great atmosphere with couches, outdoor tables, and even a bar inside.  One warning: I've seen ridiculously long lines here on sunny weekend days.  Try to come on a foggy weekday; not only will there be no line but you'll have some kick-ass ambience.
author: Wes M.

description:
I can not give it more than 3 stars,  im sorry i was in and out with in 5 minutes.  however i am giving them an extra star for having great prices.  normally for what i got which was a small coffee, a medium with a double shot, and a double shot espresso i would pay an arm load in san diego, well im not in san diego, im in frisco and everyone is a coffee nazi.  
I LOVE THAT!!! 
squeeze those butt holes for your quality coffee!!! 
i spent about 6 bucks total!  sweet mother of Jebus, thats cheap and your right around the blocks from where im staying... sweet!  one day down and 5 days ill be stopping here again!
author: Lety M.

description:
I visit this place only out of a lack of options. If another cafe opened up next door, and lowered their prices just a bit, Java Beach would have a serious run for their money. While its nice to be able to grab a beer or a coffee in the same place, be able to use wireless internet, walk to the beach, or just enjoy a sunny day, its obvious that a lack of options has allowed the owners of this place to mark up their prices. Coffee and bagels for two is usually about 15 bucks (which I find ridiculous). It is also usually pretty croweded, especially if its a nice day in the outer sunset. 

Don't get me wrong, this place isn't bad, but it could benefit from a little competition.
author: Crystal A.

description:
I like 8 balls -- 2 shots of espresso and a beer.  This is what I do before I go get blown around on the beach.  Then I come back to Java Beach and have another 8 ball.  I like 8 balls on the patio.  I like 8 balls inside at the bar.  I even like them when I'm surrounded by bored kids on their laptops but not as much.  

This place is cute.  It's obvious it was like a Mexican restaurant or something before it became king of the 8 balls.
author: Abendigo R.

description:
Sitting at this place reminds me of Santa Cruz, and I've never even been to Santa Cruz...

I'm not even sure where Santa Cruz is but as a newly post-east-coaster I have seen so many Santa Cruz t-shirts and mentions that I feel like I know it. I assume it is a laid back surf town where dogs and dread-headed hippies roam with no leash and everyone is friendly because they are either stoned or just really enjoy beautiful weather or both.

Yeah this place reminds me of that but with better coffee.

I recommend grabbing a pint of Fat Tire and sitting outside right around 6:45pm and enjoy the Sunset in Sunset. And hurry because I hear that in about a month (November) this whole neighborhood will look like the inside of a potheads lungs after an ice-bong hit. Cold and foggy. So get it while it's hot.
author: scott w.

description:
Perfect in every way!  

Free wifi, small comfy area, locals, vegan goodies, Barry's (Irish!) tea, Yerba Mate Lattes, sandwiches, smiles, brown sugar, beach location, N-Judah.

I'd move across the street just to have hot tea and bagels at 5:30 in the morning.. and then come back at 11PM for a goodnight snack.
author: Vicky B.

description:
Is this place even in SF?

Located across the street from Ocean Beach, this is an AWESOME little cafe.  Sit inside or out on the sidewalk, you're sure to fall in love with this place while basking in the sun.  The roommate and I sat in the cafe on one of the comfy couches.  We ordered iced tea (Lipton's) and a mozzarella, tomato, and pesto sandwich which came opened faced.  It was so superbly yummy!

If you're going to pay with your debit card, make sure your total is $10 or more.  There is an ATM if you need to withdrawal money.  The staff are crazy friendly and funny as all heck.  The reason I gave this place only four stars is because it is sooooo far away.  

I'll definitely be back to grab lunch and then cross the street to watch the waves crash!
author: Shane P.

description: Great little cafe.  The coffee tastes amazing, and the staff is super friendly.  It can be a bit busy at times, and hard to find a seat, but there's free wifi and lots of outlets.  Will definitely be back.
author: Cara M.

description:
Okay, Java Beach, you've seriously got me hooked with these god damned delicious sandwiches of yours.

The patrons who spill out from every corner of your modest, otherwise comfortable, environs are another story... whether it's the North Face-clad yuppies or the scraggly-haired degenerate crowd, I'm really put-off by the people who inhabit your cafe.

GREAT beer selection... fantastic breakfast menu... AMAZING sandwiches and orange juice... yummy.  I don't drink coffee, so I can't really comment on that, but it must be up to snuff 'cause this place is always slammed with all sorts of people ordering all kinds of confusing sounding beverages.
author: Blake C.

description: Can't think of a better cafe. Right by the ocean, friendly staff, always delicious food and drinks. Great vibes at all times and perfect before work or for a long Sunday morning hang out. I've been a fan since my first visit 3 years ago and keep coming back. Their 3-cheese veggie sandwich is only rivaled by their hummus bagel sandwich. Their soups are perfect for the foggy days. I love their patio and pretty much everything about it.
author: Adrianna M.

description:
I wanted to like this place more than I did. Yes, the coffee was excellent. The cheese sandwich was good (although small), The location was great - right by the beach - perfect for a snack before and after catching some healthy sea air. Guinness and coffee available at the same venue - what more could a "family" outing ask for?

It was a chilly day, but we were determined to sit outside with the pooch and enjoy the great outdoors before our stroll. We braved the elements and enjoy it we did.

So why just three stars? They lose a star for service. There was a long line waiting for counter service. The staff (at least the one that serverd us) unhelpful ("do you have wholewheatl bagels?"; "no"; "ok - shall we play 20-questions or why don't you just tell me what you have?"; "can I have the soup special - vegetarian minestrone" "no - I think there's none left"; "ok - would you please check... and take it off the chalk-board so that I don't wait in line for 20 minutes for the hard-written special that is all gone?"). The latte was prepared prepared quickly and well; but the Guinnes took another 10 minutes and stood on the counter for 5 more until we asked for it!

I understand that people can have a bad day, but this was beyond the pale. I can imagine that this place is a zoo on a suuny day when everyone heads for the beach, but on a quiet, gloomy day when we made an effort to head to the beach to patronize this establishment, one would hope they would make an effort too.
author: Kingpin X.

description: Great outdoor seating and the lemon bars are a tasty treat. Coffee was okay.
author: Monica H.

description: Great coffee and pastries in the morning, delicious sandwiches during the day, and beer on tap at night.  I could live inside this restaurant.  Perfect spot to pick up gear for a day at the beach.
author: Neal N.

description: Caramel Latte was way too sweet. I didn't even finish it.
author: Eric W.

description: Location Location Location! Good eats and Good drinks, too. If you're in the area, worth stopping by for a snack or a meal!
author: Razel F.

description:
**UPDATE:  Man - they install a couple POS registers and start charging extra for everything! I liked it better when they didn't have any idea what their profit margin was.  They've gotten stingy on the cream cheese, too.**

My place to go when I'm out milk, or out of food.  OK truth be told, I'm just too hung over to manage putting together anything consumable in the morning (aka noon).  My staple sandwich is the veggie bagel w/poppyseed bagel, no onions: they toast the bagel then layer up tomato slices, lettuce, and alfalfa, and a thick slab o' cream cheese.
author: CINDY K.

description:
Ben R., let's get your cultural anthropology straight! This weren't no Mexican restaurant back in the day; can you not see that it screams 'old mucker Irish bar' in the biggest, loudest way? :D 

In fact, the bar's still there. Belly up and swill your latte, vino, or beer. Nice selection of beer, if you're into that sort of thing, which I'm not, but hey. To each their own. 

This is a Wood Extravaganza. Wood paneling, wood bar, wood floor, wood chalet-ish ceiling, and some funky broke-down couches that some former bachelor doubtlessly was ordered to jettison by his new bride in favor of an overstuffed chenille suite, but I digress. 

Good soups. Great sandwiches (heated!). HELL of pastry (and donuts!) to choose from. A cornucopia of coffee from which to choose. My only complaint is the occasionally-acid service (getting better, though, or maybe I'm just getting more thick-skinned) and it's almost always crowded, but what do you want? It's at the beach. 

Nice little neighborhood hangout, and I'm SO glad it's there. It's nice that there are still some kinda broke-down, funky cafes left in a sea of Starbuckization. 

Another plus: they open EARLY and are open LATE. Especially for Siberia (the Outer Sunset).
author: Cake M.

description: This cafe is amazing! Great ambience, super friendly staff, and fun people/locals. Coffee...I was buzzing off their espresso blend which the barista told me was her favorite, so I endulged. I just found my new coffee shop in SF!
author: David N.

description: Java beach is a really nice place!! I have been there three times. It's relaxing to see the sunset there. Coffee is okay and sandwiches are amazing!! I like to go there and sit at the terrace enjoying the weather. That`s one of my first places that I visited in San Francisco. It`s a little bit small inside. You can connect your laptop and drink your coffee in a big sofa. Sometimes there are too many people and the crowd  and it feels crowded.
author: Alex R.

description:
There is nothin' redeeming about this place.  The food is bad, the service is the worst EVER.  I mean really, what on earth did I do to you that you treat me so badly for ordering a cup of drip coffee and a bagel.  You aren't having a bad day, you are having a bad life Java Beach.  Really.  The only people that get good service here are the beach bums (and I mean bums) that hang out all day near the door (or pass out on the grassy knoll across the way) and stink up the joint.  Sorry, I know so of you love it but, this place is awful.

***Sorry, rant is over now. Didn't know that was going to happen.
author: Thadd L.

description:
Good selection of snacks and even unsweetened AND sweetened CHAIS to choose from! I'm so excited!! And of course soy milk for those of us who are lactose-challenged and brown-sugar for those who wish to have a richer sugar kick in our drinks...

And wait, how can I forget the brownies?!!?!?!? Crack brownies I like to call them because they are so damn good I will drive down to this little cafe JUST FOR A BROWNIE! And I don't even like cake, cookies, or chocolate (see my Sprinkles review) but damn dude, I cannot get enough of these little pieces of rich gooey soft on the inside and oh so slightly crispy on the outside cocoa goodness! Break me off a piece of THAT!!
author: Christy M.

description: This place has great sandwiches and is very easy going.  Always busy and packed full of people doing work and stuff.  Close to the beach.
author: David C.

description: Great local place for coffee and food!!!
author: Christa B.

description: They have the best hot subs around. Get a large to split with someone. Super sized with the works for about $9. Feed two easily. Ask for extra toasty because sometimes its so thick the center stays cold.
author: Chris N.

description:
My first trip there  - unsweetened iced tea with lemon - yum! My second trip - cappucino with a croissant...soooo good.

The boy had his usual triple espresso over ice.

I like the location (right across from Ocean Beach); always busy inside and great staff. Maybe I'll go back next time and try one of their fresh juices. Mmmmmmm.
author: Manda S.

description: Sandwiches are great, but the Kelly Cove with avocado is definitely my favorite. Also on a cold day there steamed vanilla milk is delightful :)
author: Anthony S.

description:
After a day of schlepping my stuff to a new apartment in the richmond, my helpful moving-buddy suggested we go to Java Beach for lunch. I've never thought to myself, "hey, let's get a hot sub sandwich!" BUT after Java Beach...maaaaaybeeeee.

I had: hot veggie sub. 
He had: hot tsunami sub. 
Both looked & tasted amazing. 

It was crowded, but that's because Java Beach customers know what's up.
author: Nikki H.

description: Coffee was good, staff seem happy to see you, pretty busy, wish it was in my neighborhood. Seems like it would be good place hang out
author: Adam O.

description:
Where the surfers and skaters of the sunset go to get a pint or pitcher after work and sit in the sun on the street!

I go here every single day and the location, if you live in the Sunset, cannot be beat. You are a block from GG Park, a block from the beach, and you have all the espresso you would want, as well as free wifi, amazing sandwiches and salads, and a decent selection of beers. You can even drink beer outside on the street, which is just about one my favorite things to do on a sunny day in SF. 

I used to live on the same block. Everyone knows me by name. It is an uber-busy shop these days, and the coffee is not my favorite, but it does do the trick and gets my day started in a place that I love. They also have wicked sub sandwiches that are huge and dripping with sauce. If you like hanging out by the beach in a low-key place (surfers, hippies, yuppies, firemen, skaters, FBI agents--everyone comes here), this is the place for you. It's also a bit of en enclave for skaters. I've seen the Sector 9 crew hanging here. 

The block it is on is probably one of my favorite places in all of SF (don't tell anyone, they'll come out here and ruin it). Don't expect the waitstaff to be impressed with what you're ordering or with you. This is not that kind of place. These--mostly girl--servers work thier butts off all day and are just trying to get their work done and to help you as quickly as possible. They also have some raspberry crumble bars that are delicious. Basically, this is a surf rat coffee shop a block from ocean beach (where the N-Judah turns around).
author: Rob T.

description:
My friend had invited me here one day to have coffee and chat.
It's a vibrant and friendly neighborhood coffee shop.
I didn't drink coffee so I order tea and some pastry, my friend order coffee.
We had shared our pastry and chat.
I enjoyed  this place and we had a good time.
author: Kim L.

description: So I live near this cafe went here a few times and my favorite thing to order is the subzero frozen hot chocolate I believe its called...I would have given this place 5 stars because of the great vibe and great food, but one time I was there I ordered a bagel with cream cheese and a frozen hot chocolate...so I get my drink and I'm waiting for my bagel which doesn't come for half an hour..I mean it might have been my fault for not speaking up but I mean come on! It was a slow night I was sitting up at the counter with my friend waiting for my bagel and three times a staff member would come up ask what I was waiting for, apologize for forgetting, walk to the kitchen, and never appear again...so hopefully that was just an off night since it only happened once when I went there...but who knows..
author: Michael S.

description:
Cold, sunny, & windy summer day, my friend decided to take us here. Cozy place, pretty warm, & just had an overall welcoming atmosphere. A great place to just kickback & catch up with friends, although the majority of people here were college kids or a little older, people stuck in books & newspapers in such a lively venue. Free Wi-Fi like many have previously mentioned.

I have to come back to try the foods they offer here. We got somewhat of a teaser when we tried the frozen hot chocolate. Definitely familiar, but great anytime of the day! Back again soon.
author: Mike M.

description:
A home away from home.  Love grabbing a cuppa Joe & a warmed croissant sandwich...cookies are tempting. 

The place is roomy & cozy, with in & outdoor seating, a bar, couches and decent bathrooms ('k, I can only vouch for the door with the skirt).

Great location at the end of the N-Line (in case you doze off along the way), esp. on a lazy sunny day.  Good for both people watching and dogs (on the outside).
author: Cathy K.

description:
Good things:
- Coffee
- Bagel
- Waves
- Sunshine
- Kristi
- Good conversation
- Weather warm enough to lay out on Ocean Beach
- Holiday right smack in the middle of the week!

Today was a good day.  

It was packed on this 4th of July but they were good at keeping things moving smoothly.  The staff is friendly and their goods are good!  I love this place!  It's perfectly located and reminds me of beachside coffeehouses from my days in SoCal.  *Sigh*
author: Nicole N.

description:
After my first visit, I thought I'd love it. I was lucky once. But after going numerous times, I concluded that the workers & service suck!!!!! My friend who used to work there even said "yeah the workers don't care & don't give a shit" 
It's the tasty food that gives them the stars ..other than that, it's whack. 

Does it really take 45 minutes to make 2 veggie subs?

Thankfully the Java Beach on Sloat  has finally opened...much better service.
author: Alexa M.

description:
We used to go here in highschool, there wasn't many places for highschool age Sunset Natives to hangout, and we always knew we were never going to run into anyone we knew there.

I blame the TV show Friends, because by Senior year, everyone from our highschool was here and we lost our little corner. I knew it was getting more and more popular when I went off to college, but I really never expected it to become as popular as it is now!

I come home to find this place PACKED and with fair reason. The old couches are gone, and it has a new coat of paint. The seating outdoors is really nice, and actually overall the place looks so much nicer than it used to.

They still have their variety of coffees for you to pump, along with the typical espresso drinks and tasty sandwiches. It is hard to find a place to sit, and people will hover to get your table. But, if you can score a seat, it is a nice place to people watch while having a nosh.

With all the little positives they have, I will never understand why the service here is so bad. Even before they were so popular the service sucked, and it still sucks today. 

Between the crowds and the service I would much rather go to the Sea Biscuit, but then again there is something about sitting in the fog, inches from the beach, and snuggling that latte...

I'm torn on Java Beach, but I think in the end I'll leave it for the tourists and those willing to put up with snarly service and wrestling match for a stool.
author: Dixon T.

description:
Love Java Beach.  On a nice day it's such a treat to sit outside and enjoy a warm tea and bagel.  It's very popular so it can be hard to snag a table.  But if you hover like I do, it doesn't take long before you're snatching a table outside.  

I got "my" breakfast bagel - everything bagel, cream cheese, tomatoes, cucumber.  They served it open faced - major points for that.  The ingredients were fresh and I really enjoyed it.  I imagine if I got it to-go it would have been sandwich style but it would still be really good I'm sure.  On my high list for my bagel but it's far from my house so only on special occasions do I venture out.  

If I lived in the 'hood, I would be there every morning.
author: Alice H.

description:
Java Beach is perfect for what it is:
- Coffee : Strong House Coffee, Espresso drinks, Pastries, Sandwiches and BEER!
- Atmosphere: Couches, Free Wireless, Outlets so you can camp out. Perfect to get that paper done or to work from "home"
- Community: LIVE music and Local artists hang on the walls
(FunFact from Native: Although it looks like the place is a converted beach bungalow, the building was once home to a jazz joint in the thirties)
- Transport: End of the N-Judah Line 
- Location: Across the street from Ocean Beach.
author: Elizabeth F.

description:
I'm always wary of visiting places that are "at the end of the line." I think it stems from my horrid experience in visiting Coney Island.  This is why I have yet to visit Pittsburg/Bay Point, Shady Grove, or Van Cortlandt Park. 

However, there's nothing frightening about the end of the N-Judah. This place is awesome. 

Gets crowded, but there's free wifi. Good music and a great mix of people. My latte wasn't as strong as what you'd find at Cole Coffee in Rockridge, but it'll do. The atmosphere is enough to keep me awake and functioning. 

Perfect place to get some work done.
author: Marc P.

description:
One star for location.

One star for being open when I really needed caffeine.

But the prices are way too high. The place is also really small, always crowded, and load. And the service is not friendly; they always come across as lazy workers that are bored out of their skulls.
author: Diana H.

description: If you want good coffee, walk up the street to Trouble.
author: Colleen C.

description:
Nice corner coffee shop with far too many people during the day.  I've tried to come here to relax, have a latte, and surf the net--I mean get some work done-on several occasions but the place is usually packed even during the work days (geez, don't you people work in offices anymore?).  Rightly so, Java Beach serves some of the best chai I've ever had.

Atmosphere
Like any other corner coffee shop, except by the beach and the occasional guitar player outside.

Drinks/Food
As I mentioned above, the chai is great.  Their lattes are also very well made (not too sweet).  Their snacks and sandwiches are delectable.
They also serve some beer if you get bored of the caffeine.  

Service
They make good drinks and snack food.
author: Billy C.

description:
This is my Sunset spot! Its a few blocks from where I live, so I hold a lot of my meetings there. I was just there with my business partners a few days ago where we sat in that little makeshift garden out front eating the best vegan chocolate chip cookies with our coffees!

I love that they close late cuz I can easily take my late walk and grab a cup of good mocha on my way. I do hate that it can be extremely crowded but can you really blame the crown when they've got some good stuff to share!?
author: Ms. Hala A.

description:
A great atmosphere and good coffee, though on food alone, I can't quite give the fourth star as the parfait was made with whole yogurt.

Yuck.

But.

Java Beach earns that fourth star because you can take all that to go (minus the yogurt of course), walk across the street to the beach, and eat while watching the ocean on what was an incredibly summer like day in November.

Yay.
author: Jason B.

description: very pretty area. crowded and they stuff their sandwiches like a mad person. haha! i had the chicken with back and pepper jack cheese. It was good. the honey mustard was meh, a little too sweet for me, but all in all a very solid lunch. I did appreciate that the people were friendly and the service was pretty fast. I don't know if i'd be back but it was a nice spot to try on a whim.
author: Janet D.

description: I parked my bike about a block away since it's always always ALWAYS filled with bicyclists and I just didn't want to fight for a space.  I had a great time drinking my earl grey tea and people watching.  The best one today was a white male: late 40's to early 50's, Jheri curl, leather converse like shoes and a fanny pack!  Win-Win-Win!
author: Ashley I.

description:
Haven't been here in a few months, but here I go anyway -- decent coffee, free Wi-Fi when it's working, friendly folks behind the counter, biiiiig slices of cake for dessert, good basic toasted bagels, and there's something they put in the Tsunami sandwich that's pretty darn good. Something about the mayo, perhaps?

I used to grade exams here: pound down cups of coffee until happy hour, then pound down pints of Stella as the stack of graded bluebooks grew higher than the stack of ungraded ones. I don't think I gave out more A's after 5 pm though, contrary to what it may sound like.

Downside: generally pretty grimy, but there's a lot of sand on the beach, you know? On sunny days it's impossible to find a place to sit. Fairly yuppie-free, thank goodness. Lots of folks with leathery tans though. Every morning it smells of coffee and bagels; on sunny afternoons it smells of sunscreen and armpit, but you know about the Outer Sunset's tenuous relationship with the sun.
author: Sunny V.

description:
This place has exactly what I want in a coffee shop - yummy sandwiches, decent coffee, and free wifi. The fact that it's across from the beach and I can go for a run after a few hours of working makes it extra special.

The hot veggie sandwich is great, and I'm VERY picky about my sandwiches. It even comes with some tasty crinkle-cut potato chips.

A bonus and a drawback is the clientele- mostly down-to-earth whatever types, but the occasional smelly drifter can really diminish the generally positive ocean-fresh olfactory experience.
author: LeeLee P.

description:
I started going to Java Beach simply because it was around the corner from my apartment, I kept going because it's just a great coffee shop ala San Francisco native.

Not Caffe Trieste, certainly not S.B., just real coffee, really nice people and a San Francisco atmosphere. The staff is great and I still remember many of people that have worked there in years past ... Stacy, Nicole and the ones that work there now.

So if you want a good cup of Joe, some San Francisco aura and a great sandwich, go to the Beach, Java Beach.
author: Ray S.

description:
This is our favorite coffee shop in San Francisco. It's close to the beach and serves warm beverages, pastries, and alcoholic drinks. You can bring in your laptop and do some school work inside, as well as hang out under the stars any given night nature allows.

I promise you will be convinced the moment you take a sip of your first latte.

The hot chocolate is my fave.
author: Mira T.

description: This place is very cool, right by the ocean, right where the N Judah turns around. Outdoor seating, facing west. It's classic SF. Smell the ocean with your cup of joe. Inside set-up is right on the $: Lounging on the left, main counter on the right, a small bar with beers on tap in the back, and a make-shift area for small musical acts. Good prices, friendly staff.
author: Boom Z.

description: WOOOOOO. I feel like I have found my cafe. The sandwiches are amazing, the cafe is crackin, and the coffee is good.  The location can make it difficult to study because I want to cross the road and frolic in the sand, but I fight the feeling.
author: Josie A.

description:
This review may be premature as I'm determined to compare and contrast Java Beach Cafe's hot turkey and pepper jack sandwich, the works, on dutch crunch with Freddy's Ocean Beach sandwich. But having just eaten at Java Beach today - I felt it was important to capture the essence immediately.

Medium sandwich came with crispy, delicious crinkle cut chips. Dutch crunch was fresh and crusty. Most notable aspect of the sandwich was the perfect amount of spicy pepperchinis and pickles to sweet bread. Sandwich and large ice tea came to exactly $10. Credit/Debit minimum of $5 on your card, just in case you're out of cash.

Stay tuned for the winner of Java Beach vs. Freddy's hot sandwich showdown.
author: Jenny T.

description: I've been coming here since January. I've become a regular. Debbie and Megan who work here are awesome.
author: Michael M.

description: I adore this place and drive across the city often just to go there and study. It has that cozy, neighborly coffee shop vibe that makes me want to hang out all day. Close to the water, killer vanilla latte (the best foam!), and super nice staff.
author: Lindsay A.

description:
Perfect location: a block from the beach.

My friend was able to get her rice milk chai... this is amazing.

I had steamed milk (flavored with hazelnut) and then walked to the beach to enjoy. What a lovely San Francisco afternoon treat!
author: Flora B.

description:
Pretty much one of the only little and good cafe's way out there.  I have gone with my surfer friends to get oatmeal in the morning.  And I have gone out there on a sunny day to study or read.  One night when I went they had an open mic night which was great.  I saw a documentary about a local surfer dude.
I don't remember much about the food other than it wasn't especially bad or especially good.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Bonfire Delight sandwich with sprouts- yum yum yum. Perfection in the form of a latte.

Great little cafe with quite the neighborhood following.  Friendly folks, too. Win-win.
author: May W.

description:
Java Beach is a good place to grab something warm to drink before/after a walk along the beach. They also open at 6am every day so its great for early risers

I've only had their coffee and bagels (both good). They also serve sandwiches and have a decent selection of beers as well
author: Bumble B.

description:
A funky little cafe. Four star for location and SF beach atmosphere. I'm not a coffee expert, so my opinion doesn't count for much other than it's good too sit on one of the couches and sip a latte while reading the Guardian and people watching.

I used to live in the neighborhood and would drop by now and again. A stop by this Saturday brought back nostalgia.
author: Paul T.

description:
When you walk into the Java Beach, it's like you've been transported to Pacific Beach, San Diego.  Although I'm not a huge fan of the vibe in SD, but Java Beach provides San Franciscans with a reprieve from the sometimes stuffy confines of the urban coffee shop.

I happen to be here on a warm sunny day without a hint of wind.  The coffee is strong good and although I haven't had the food, the menu looks like it would be good for lunch.  They don't call out their drink orders loud enough and I ended up waiting for my iced coffee for 3-4 minutes without realizing that it was ready and on the counter.
