Free wifi is good, and they have couches and several tables inside and outside to enjoy the paper or surf the internet.  There's a good mix of locals, old, young, black, white, brown, etc.  Very comfortable...
author: Mike T.

description: When my husband and I moved out to the outer sunset we had no idea we would be greeted by the best latte's and sandwich place in S.F. The people are friendly and get to know you. My husbands favorite sandwich is there. And I can't resist grabbing a latte and walking over to the beach. Thanks for being amazing!
author: amy g.

description: Amazing food. Great sandwiches and coffee and chocolate croissants. You have to wait a bit for your food, but its worth it.
author: jamie b.

description:
JB is a gem in the Avenues. It's pretty much the only game in town, and it's good for early coffee (I've grabbed coffee at 6 am, right before heading to golf), brunch, afternoon drop by, and evening drinks. The Tsunami sandwich is the best sandwich in all of SF; for real. 

I also cherish JB because that is where I've taken my daughter since she was 1 1/2 (she's now 2 yrs 8 months) for a cookie, and now a hot chocolate as well.
author: Alex T.

description:
I always heard all my girl friends talk about this awesome place called Java beach. Okay, I'll give it a shot.

The place is quite cozy. I like the ambiance and vibe of it, and the whole block-away-the-beach helps. So I order and go in line. I order a some sort of turkey sandwich and take a seat and talk amongst my friends. A while passed and most of my friends got their orders and I haven't gotten mine. it's lunch time, i'm hungry, and i dont have food infront of me. That's a bad mix for gabe.

so i tell the counter to follow up on my order. couple of minutes passed and I got it. Could they have forgotten my order? hmmm? maybe.

But the sandwich wasn't all the rave. I need to learn not to trust hypes too often. Maybe their coffee is the one that started its fame. But since I'm not a big coffee drinker, I'll have to give this place and a-ok.
author: Gabe R.

description:
Urban living inevitably means being exposed to details of other peoples' lives. I accept that.

Where I draw the line is the loud Russian woman on the couch at Java Beach, scheduling her MRI. On her cell phone. Loudly.

I can't blame Java Beach for this, but I can penalize it for its confusing setup -- tables and chairs everywhere, kind of a messy scenario. However, the turkey sandwich I'm eating is good, the coffee is definitely decent (and in a pint glass, which I like), and there's free wifi and plenty of pluggage.

Still, if I didn't have to be here for a meeting today, I can't say I would be. And as for the Russian woman: Just die already! OK, maybe I sound like a bitch. But it's just that kind of day.
author: Allison L.

description:
Sometimes I like to take the N to the end of the line.  It could be because I want to go to the beach.  Or perhaps I need to get rid of something via a Craigslist transaction (note I said TRANSACTION, not 'hook-up').

The area around this establishment is nothing but old Chinese ladies in fuschia windbreakers and bad perms, and houses.  What a nice surprise to find a corner coffee house that not only has a bar, but a large menu of sandwiches (breakfast ones too!)?  They have all the bare essentials too, 'course.

The music was choice (Blondie, Belinda Carlisle, Doors, Eagles), the WiFi was not WEP protected, the service was friendly.  If there's ever a tsunami off the coast of SF, I'll probably help rebuild this place, and that's saying a lot.
author: Lily E.

description: I used to go here all the time for bagels and stuff, my boyfriend always got coffee. The coffee is good, and the espresso drinks are great! The bagels are good, especially the breakfast one! The smoothies aren't that good, although I did get them anyway when I was craving some fruit, they are really big.
author: Helen K.

description: The selection of coffee that the owner brings in are well chosen.  I am a black coffee, I want to taste the roasted bean, type of guy.  Food is also large and filling.  Word of advice--Get their early or hate yourself for not while you wait in a long line.
author: Luciano A.

description:
Ahhh.... having moved here from the North... I miss the casual surfer coffeeshops.. where you can feel so cozy homey sippin on some organic joe and pass the time without a care in the world. So I was glad to have ran out of coffee beans and having to saunter out iso a great cup.. 
T'was a nice slow weekend afternoon, forced to be without ambition as I was recovering from first-week-capoeira-class soreness. The sun was out, a rare occasion in the Sunset, and wanting to take advantage of that, this cafe came into mind.  With a book in hand, for several hours, I mellowed at a sunny table by the window, with feet up, drinking on a soy cappuccino..  perfectly relaxed with the casualness and the comfort smells of this idyllic oceanside hangout..
author: Vicky P.

description:
Over rated

It's a great idea which I would love to enjoy, but then the experience becomes smothered and turns into agony.  I wait and wait and wait, babies cry, mean glares dart in my direction, people won't even nudge as politely try to retrieve my food at the end of the counter.

I have learned to be smart and selective about the times I choose to come here.  The food is not bad, the rolls=very good, but you still feel horrible ordering because everyone working is either robotic or completely rude, and you feel as if you are throwing gas on a fire.

I will continue to go here when I stop by ocean beach but I must prepare myself for the possibilities of dealing with loads of stroller moms and rude hipster surfers who are "too cool".

I love the fact that there is usually a plethora of cute dogs waiting outside.
author: Diana D.

description:
Thank you Java Beach for feeding me delicious bagels, muffins, coffee and hot chocolate when I was starving, and for feeding my internet obsession with free wi fi while i lived across the street from you for those 2 glorious months.

I will be forever grateful to you for staying open late and letting me munch away my "no-net-at-home"sorrows and for giving me a haven to run to when the homeless beachgoers began to harass me.

It does get pretty busy on weekends, especially saturdays, and I remember when I first started going there, the glares from the fatties that would sit on the sofa (with no food OR drinks) when i walked in.BUT everyone who works there is super nice and people were always willing to let me have a space at their table to put my laptop and coffee on. 

i miss going here. =(
author: Diana R.

description: Get the original Ocean Beach (OB) hot beef sub...  Best deli I've had in years.
author: John W.

description:
I absolutly love this place.
I do everything here. Homework, 
chill out, have a glass of wine on a chilly night. 
Located right at the beach, with laid back reggae music, and great sandwiches. Open from 6am to 11 pm,.
People from all over the bay area come down to chill here on a Sat morning.
author: Dasha V.

description:
KILLIN' TIME ON MY DAY OFF. I loved sitting up high near the grassy area overlooking ocean beach. I'd sit there for hours, with my hoodie zipped up, my music on, and my hot cocoa in hand. Java Beach is very convenient. I don't dare use those public restrooms at the beach. Nuh uh! And whenever I was ready to go home, I'd catch the N back up the hill. 

Now I live 100 miles away. Muni doesn't come this far.
author: Michael R.

description:
Convo overheard in coffee line, on rare, 70 degree, fogless day conducted by younger version of Thomas Hayden Church look-a-like.

"Yeah dude I'm at Java Beach. No I'm talking to you on my cell phone. Yeah! I said MY CELL PHONE! Waves are pumpin' out here bra. Well wax up an' get out here pronto cause shits gonna be steamin! For sure! Yeah, an' there's tons a hotties out. Right now? I'm talkin' to on my cell phone and ordering a sandwich." 

Still the go-to place when you need eats, java, brew or sweets, in addition to free wireless.  Cindy serves up everything with a smile. For the carne lovers, try the Tsunami and ask for peppers. Great local scene complete with your OB surfers, students, beachcombers, N Judah drivers, dog walkers etc. Todays funny: Two dudes were overly critical of dudes on Hot or Not.
author: Johnny C.

description: Friendly staff, good food and excellent coffee. The WiFi is a bit spotty, and you may or may not be able to get a seat that you can work at; the place is often packed even at quieter times of day.
author: Clutch R.

description: Bagel nirvana with a sunny (the day we were there) patio from which to inhale some sea breeze.  Lots of doggies, surfers, and neighborhood grandpas lolling about with the paper.  Good stuff.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
Cappuccino= deliciousness! The guy next to me has a sandwich and the lettuce sounds so crunchy and delicious that I want one now...

Its very beachy place, so  its super casual and unpretentious. I had considered studying here after work, but after coming on a weekend afternoon, I'm not sure how well-lit it is, especially the street parking after dark....It IS open until 11pm though, that's a definite perk! =]
author: Amy L.

description:
Good food - I had a hot turkey sandwich and it was awesome.  Staff are always nice too.

There's always a line and it's usually crowded... however I've been able to find a seat every time by the time it matters.  

Their coffee by the pound is great too.  We like this place.
author: Leah M.

description: Pretty cool ambience. Busy though you have to wait in line for a minute. My sandwich was pretty good . Cool little joint.
author: Cove C.

description: The clerk was kinda rude like she did't really wanna be working or she was having a bad day, but the coffee was great!!! Great organic stuff and It is right by the N. Very convenient.
author: Kayla G.

description:
hot cup of coffee on a cold windy day at the beach. 
this place is the only shop for a few blocks and its extremely warm and cozy in there. everyone sits within inches of each other working on their laptop feeding off free wifi and drinking fair trade coffee. i had to wait a while for my coffee but the friendly service and cool cup covers (able to open and close the hole to drink) made up for the wait. definitely a place to meet some nice cool people.

and on a side note there was an asian couple ordering before me and they were trying to decide for a while and their english wasnt the best but the cashier was super friendly and nice to them. and when they finally ordered they got one large cup of coffee and a muffin and said to the cashier "we share everything ". how adorable
author: Wendy N.

description:
I just love Java Beach Cafe.

The coffee is quite good, the hot chocolate, David assures me, is great.  I love to go and get a chai latte.  Yes, there are lines on weekend mornings and noons.  I rarely go during those times.  Luckily, I live only a couple of blocks away.

Our routine is to go there as regularly as possible in the evenings to have a glass of wine (there are only two kinds - white or red - not spectacular, but palatable) and a sandwich.  I adore the cold veggie sandwich (there is a hot one, too, with melted cheese).  Oh, yum.  David nearly always gets the mozzarella and pesto sandwich.  They have many other terrific sandwiches, great salads, too, and soups.  The portions are generous.  Some of the servers are young and not overly deferential to customers, I admit.  We like to go when Debbie is there.  She is terrific.  On Friday and Saturday nights, and occasionally on other nights of the week, there is live music.

In the evenings, you get fewer of the folks who are just stopping in on their way to or from the beach.  There are more regulars and the atmosphere is relaxed and familial.  There is free wifi, so people bring their laptops.   Even when there is no live music, there is music piped through speakers in and outdoors.  Pretty mellow stuff.

The only drawback is a certain challenge in terms of space and seating.  Sometimes you have to stand a bit, or share a table, especially inside.  In nice weather, there is pleasant seating outdoors.   

Have I mentioned that I love this place?
author: Angela M.

description: After a date hanging out on Ocean Beach, we decided to find a place with something hot to drink.  Yelping a late night cafe (you win again, yelp), we drove the few blocks down to Java Beach.  The service was very friendly, especially considering it was 10:30PM on a Thursday night.  It looked like folk band had just finished playing and were taking down their set.  I guess folk music since one of them was carrying out a washboard.  They must have been good since there weren't any empty seats inside to be had.  Luckily they had a well lit patio out front with long wooden benches.  We didn't order anything elaborate, just hot chocolate and cider to keep us warm.  We were able to sit outside until closing, watching Muni trains reach the end of the line.  I really loved the feel of Java Beach Cafe late at night when the rest of the neighborhood is quiet and dark.  Definitely a good stop on the way home from Ocean Beach.
author: Daniel A.

description: After coming to Java Beach every now and then for the past 15+ years, I thought it was time to write a review.  My, oh my, have things changed from the days their doors first opened, giving life force to a neighborhood that was desperately in need of a decent hang-out spot.  It used to be just coffee and bagels/pastries, but now it's a full-fledged cafe.  Honestly, things have improved tenfold.  The interior and exterior have been cleverly re-done.  The coffee is better.  They serve great sandwiches and other food.  They have tasty chai too.  The service is really, really special.  What amazingly friendly and warm people!  Check it out when you get a chance.
author: Kandi K.

description:
Location? Superb.

Outdoor seating? Marvelous.

Prices? Astronomical. Service? Usually abhorrent. Crowded all the frickin time by upper-crust Ocean Beach bums. And pricks. Lots of pricks.

Except at night. At night, it's one of the best places in town to sip a Guinness and shoot the shit. All the jerks are gone, and the coffee-slingers with that "I'VE BEEN UP SINCE 4 A.M." attitude are in bed.

You get a 10 cent discount when you bring your travel mug... but then they give you a receipt, always, every time, even when you try to say NOTHANKS. Way to be, hippie.
author: Chris R.

description: Here's the deal, Java beach is amazing and thats all i can say. From the food, to the amazing atmosphere, to the amazing people, and the amazing music, its just a super duper chill place. Other than being amazingly chill for doing homework (with their wonderful wifi), its a great place for a date after a romantic walk on the beach and wont break the bank. The food ere is great and i don't even think that five stars is enough for this place. It warm, cozy and theres nothing like it. If you check out this place you wont regret it.
author: Anna B.

description:
This place is more than a cafe.  I'll be honest, the coffee here isn't awesome.  Everything else about it, however, is amazing.  First, there is the atmosphere.  How could you not enjoy sitting 1 block away from the Pacific.  If the wind is right you can even smell the salt from the ocean.  When it's not foggy and the sun is shining, if you aren't lucky enough to find a seat outside, there is usually a nice breeze blowing in from the many windows.  

Something that really stands out about this place is the food.  The portions are huge, and the selection is great.  This is the type of place where you'd go to hang out with your friends on a lazy Sunday, (or if you're unemployed, a lazy Tuesday) take your mother out for lunch, or, just spend hours just working away enjoying the free wifi.    

Aside from the beach, Java Beach makes the end of Judah Street a destination spot, particularly for those who like to be reminded why San Francisco is such a great place.  I do have to deduct points for the coffee though.
author: Adam E.

description:
Grabbed a bran muffin and a Guinness here following a frigid Ocean Beach surf session; what a great combo, stout and bran.  The place was packed with people on their laptops, as packed as my muffin was with raisins.

Cool venue.

Auf.
author: Dave K.

description:
I visited early one Friday morning and got a vanilla late which was fabu.
Also got a giant rice crispie treat.  (I know, random. But it's made of cereal which thereby qualifies it as breakfast food!)  It was nice and chewy and had mini m&m's on top.  Mmm mmm good. I highly recommend it!
The girl working was nice enough.
author: Chrissy S.

description:
Great location. Solid coffee. Awesome sandwiches.

Java Beach is a Sunset classic. For this, it is always busy. Not a place to relax and dive into work or a book. Sometimes the service can get slow, but it is never terrible, and is always understandable considering the amount of people in and out of the shop.
author: Mitchell C.

description: I have only gone here for coffee and pastries.  I have never found a good pastry - from a hard bran muffin, to a mediocre blueberry coffee cake to an average scone.  So I'm passing on the pastries for now.  The coffee is good, but at $2.00 for a small 12 oz cup, its not cheap.  Still, the place is cozy and nice outside dog-friendly seating.  And a great location right by the beach.
author: Dora V.

description: I'm not a coffee drinker, but this place is still a regular stop for me. They have great options for breakfast, and even better stuff for lunch. Delicious food, polite service, and a fun atmosphere. Great for stopping and grabbing food for the beach!
author: Beth W.

description:
My mother grew up in the sunset district... I believe its run by an irish family... or has that "strong" irish feel that used to dominate the Sunset district... 

It's an off beat place...where you can go read a book or chat it up with a friend...or stranger... it has a mix of locals and surfers... the cool thing is they are open late... so if you are freezing your ass off at a bonfire party... you can grab some hot chocolate to give you a pick me up
author: Peta C.

description: i really liked the space and the food was good.   menu pricing is not too bad, but the coffee price is steep [approx $3+ per cup].   albeit, the coffee cup is large and the selection is exotic - but still kinda expensive.  i'd still come back though.
author: n y.

description:
Hey Java Beach thanks for being right at the end of my long run! 

I love this cute  cafe, conveniently located right by the beach. I enjoy visiting on a weekend morning/afternoon from a long run. I sometimes cut my run short to stop in, grab some coffee or tea...and if its time for lunch... they have some decent sandwiches and what not. 

Coffee/Tea: I don't have any complaints. I wouldn't say its to die for, but its still good! I get my usual soy hazelnut latte, and i've had their ice tea which isn't bad as well. 

Food: Well I've only ordered a sandwich before...but it wasn't too bad. Their hot sandwiches are good :) 

Environment: cute little cafe. It gets pretty crowded on the weekends, and i've had to wait in a line before...but the wait isn't that bad. Small, so if you want a seat, keep your eye out. I always like sitting outside in the little patio. Just bundle up if its a chilly day! Also right in front of the N Judah turn around...in case you are wondering about transportation.

Service: I have no complaints with the service. They are fairly nice, and I haven't had any problems. The customers have been pleasant as well, and always run into someone who makes small talk. 

:) See ya on my next run!
author: Catherine O.

description:
Coffee is great...
Sandwiches are great...
Free internet, convenient nice location off the N Judah is also a plus.

Over the year's I've hung out with friends, family, wrote term papers back in college to having  informal business meetings here. It's been a good all around location for me. I don't frequent there as much because I'm not living out there anymore but the N line makes it a good destination on a sunny day to the beach...
author: armando r.

description:
I love this cafe!
So good.  I love sitting here and reading, secretly people-watching.
Even though their sofa is the least comfortable sofa I have ever sat in.  

They have shows too, which is always fun.
author: Leila-Anne C.

description:
What a wonderful establishment.

What a great place to just feel like your living life.  I love people watching.  I know, I am one of those, but it really makes me feel alive to just watch how different and how cool people can be.  I love coming here to just read the paper, or grab a latte and take a walk on the beach.

Awesome, couldn't  be better if it was next door to  my house, location.  On the corner of The Great Highway and Judah in San Francisco  Sunset resides my precious little Java Beach.  Don't shy away because of the long line, it moves fast and you might even make a new friend while you wait.

The coffee is delish!  Did I just say delish?  The baristas are always the same chicks and they're friendly and cool.  I actually ran into one of em at a local sunset bar (the Shannon Arms) and she was like, "Hey, you come to Java Beach!",  (I am so lame for mentioning that).   Well, anyways, no matter what drink you order they will make it with tender loving care.  :)

Okay,  now the food portion of the menu aint to shabby!  Always fresh pastries, bagels (mmm, try the vegi bagel), cookies, and cakes!

The deli sandwiches are also amazing!  But this is where its only a 4 star rating for me.  There has got to be a better system to speed up the sandwich making.  It is a long wait.  But who minds waiting when you have a lovely patio next to the beach, great San Franciscan people, wifi, a BAR!  Yes folks, a bar, well I mean some beers on tap.  But this is fantastic!  At the beach and don't want coffee, get a damn pitcher of Sierra Nevada!  mmm mmm good!

I miss living a few blocks from this place!
author: Jennifer M.

description: The behind the counter folks are just pleasant enough and going at 90 m.p.h. to keep up with demand.  And this spot at the end of the N Line and a few steps from the ocean is dinky (okay, just small) and really crowded (I had trouble finding a place to stand and wait for my to-go order).  Impressive, tho, how hot my Muddy Waters stayed the duration of a walk by the water on a chillier day.
author: Poet D.

description: They are good at taking orders, not so good at handing them out. 40 min wait for a sandwich is not worth it. They should let customers know an estimated wait time when taking the order so that you don't have to waste a beautiful day waiting for your food.
author: Hernando B.

description:
2 reasons:

frozen hot chocolate and the tsunami sub.
author: Maria M.

description:
what a great business sense this owner has! The food is consistently awesome, they never over charge, the staff is warm & enthusiastic and they seem to have no turnover!! Study or work online near the beach while enjoying a perfect breakfast or lunch!

My favorite things to order:
Bernie's blend cup of joe
Yerba matte
Frozen hot chocolate on hot days
Bagels and soups are bomb
Stacey's Mexican salad, tsunami sub, bbq chicken sando w cheddar and even their fruit bowl rocks!!

- 1 star because there is always something missing from my to go orders :( the chicken I pay extra for on my salad, the sides of dressing or the chips w/ my sandwich! Please start double checking.. this could  really ruin someones meal. 

Victoria & the blond British girl are customer service rock stars & even remember guests names :)

Java is a must do!!
author: Cecilia M.

description:
It's 4:49 & I'm watching the clock.

I don't usually leave work at 5pm. I stay late nearly every night. But we're right in the midst of an early May heatwave, & all I really wanna do is rush home, put on some shorts & ride my bike through GGP all the way out to the shimmering Pacific. I'll stop & admire the view for a few, then swing down to Java Beach to pick up a nice cold caffeinated beverage.

Java Beach is one of the very best places to be on a warm, sunny day in San Francisco.
author: Pete J.

description:
I love this place not just because it gives me an excuse to stop running but because it is a cool place to hang out. I love the handwritten menus and the couch. My friends and I come here pretty often to reminisce about our youths and the trials and tribulations of dealing with or in my case looking for a career. 

Sometimes we stop by for a pre-dinner coffee and end up staying. I love this place, it motivates me to find a really good paying job so i can afford to live near here.
author: Alia D.

description:
Things I like about Java Beach Cafe:
1. The whipped cream is really good.
2. The mochas aren't bad.
3. It's by the beach.
4. The couches are comfy.
5. Warm, worn-in, homey atmosphere, good for studying/reading.
6. Free wireless internet.

Things I don't like about Java Beach Cafe:
1. It's kind of shady in that area when the sun goes down.
2. The music gets annoying after a while. If there was a little more variety I'd be happy..but that's just me being picky.
3. $10 credit card minimum, so just bring cash if all you want is a drink.

Overall a fun place to grab a drink before watching the sunset.
author: Liz L.

description: I used to like this place more before everyone found out about it. It was great a few years ago, but now finding a seat on a Tuesday afternoon is tricky. The food is still good, the coffee is decent and the staff is friendly with the clientele being really laid back. Don't come if you don't like dogs though. There'll always be a few around laying right out in front.
author: Eric K.

description: Coffee is good. Food is great. Beer on tap is awesome. Wifi is convenient. Staff is friendly and helpful. It's almost like I never left Santa Cruz. Seriously though, the sandwiches are way too good.
author: Nick S.

description: Love grabbing a cold drink here and chilling out on the patio after a day at the beach.  Even though it's really busy, I always find seating.  There are some characters that hang out here but it's a great mix of people and the staff is friendly.  It may take a while to get your drink but that's because they have so many customers and they take the time to make good drinks.
author: Kelly H.

description: So on a visit to see my lovely and talented daughter in one of my favorite parts of the city, the outer sunset, she decided we should wander down to Java Beach Cafe and grab a quick bite.  The vibe is definitely hipsters and casual city follks but it was a very diverse crowd and I felt quite comfortable.  It is a bit warm inside so prepare to take off layers if it is chilly outside but the internet cafe portion gets crowded so sitting outside is always an option.  Right near the beach and not too heavily travelled street you can feel rather cozy just hanging out in front.  So we ordered a lemonade each and a roast beef sandwich and got a nice little spot on the sidewalk out front.  Dog friendly and bikes parked in various spots, there were definitely younger folks loitering with intent but again, it was a comfortable spot no one seemed to notice the other.  The lemonade was crisp and refreshing and perfect to sip while listening to the waves on the beach.  The sandwiches do take a bit of time to prepare but they tell you the window of time that you will wait when you order, in my case 15 minutes.  Now if you are starving, that might seem like an eternity.  However, the sandwich is so worth the wait, probably the best deli sandwich I have had in years.  The bread was fresh, as was the roast beef, it was so delicious I wish I lived closer to SF to visit more often.  Again, not perfect with the inside temperature and the wait time but if you are in the right frame of mind, it is truly a fun little spot to stop and hang out.  Stop on by if you are in the area....
author: Tristan F.

description:
The coffee I give a 5. Hands down the BEST coffee in the city. My favorite is the Hazelnut. 

However, the female staff is not very friendly. 

(The veggie sandwich makes for a yummy lunch)
author: Melinda Q.

description:
Good coffee (lots of choices)
Good bagel (very fresh, lightly toasted with cream cheese)
Comfy couches
Free wireless
Serves beer
Outdoor seating right by the beach where you can hear the waves and smell the salt air. 

My kind of spot. A bit of a hike from where I live and it got really crowded quickly but worth the trip.
author: Scott T.

description:
Charming coffee house just a few minutes walk from the beach. Good food, good beer on tap (yes! on tap!), good espresso drinks. Definitely try either the hazelnut latte or soy chai latte. You also can't go wrong with the pumpkin spice.

Free WiFi! Be warned: it gets pretty crowded with little seating indoors, so bring a jacket and sit outside.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
Love this place.  Free wireless internet.  Great sandwiches.  Prices aren't too bad either.  A cool place to hang out...but hard to find a table especially if you can't sit outside because of the rain.  

They have happy hour too.
author: Paul S.

description:
I'm not sure why I continue to go here. I guess it's just that I'm from the neighborhood and want to support the locals. Their pastries are hit or miss. Their mochas are chalky. They're always crowded, especially on hot days. I guess I'm always hopeful that it will be better the next time.

Nothing spectacular here. But it's convenient... if you want to double park and block traffic even though there's a 2 car N Judah blocking the other half of the street. 

But, on a good note, I had a bear claw there this morning that was oozing with almond paste. That brought my rating from 2 to 3 stars.
author: Valerie V.

description:
It's taken me a very long time to first realize, then admit, that I don't like this place. Not really at all. 

I felt pressured to like it my whole life, as I grew up just down the Great Highway on Rivera. It was always seen as the hip, cool place to walk the dog and sit. The only problem is, the dog hated waiting outside and there was never any place to sit. 

Now, even that might not have been a problem, but the reason there was no place to sit is that all the seats were packed with people and their various accoutrement. Now, even THAT might not have been a problem if the people were nice. And there was the problem.

The entire place full of regulars (and I swear, no matter what day or time of day I've gone in, the same regulars are always there, which leads to another post altogether) seems to hush when someone new walks in. I don't know if I didn't fit into their idea of "Sunset grunge" or what, but I definitely did not feel welcome. In fact, I almost felt ridiculed. And my tea was shit...and how do you screw up tea? 

Great place to go if you want to feel mocked by grungy hipsters...if you want to be treated like a human being, look elsewhere.

Two stars for close proximity (though thankfully, not any more).
author: Annie B.

description:
First off, this place would've gotten an easy 4 stars from me for their great sandwiches and drinks. But the wait is absolutely ridiculous. Minus one star for that immediately. 

Good stuff:
I've tried a couple of things from this cute little cafe by the beach. I've had the non-toasted veggie sandwich and the sprouts seriously complete that for me. But the TOASTED veggie sub, ohhh my god. I could have that any day and never get sick of it. It's warm and slightly crunchy with avocadoes and other things and of course, sprouts! Blueberry muffins are just the perfect amount of sweetness and the pesto veggie bagel is something I haven't had in awhile but will again soon. And let me tell ya, I think their vanilla latte is the best one I have EVER had. And I have had quite a few vanilla lattes. This one beats all.

Bad news:
And this is just too unfortunate. TAKES WAY TOO LONG. One time my friend and I ordered our sandwiches TO GO and had to wait about 45 minutes. Other people that came after us were coming and going like everything was perfect in the world while we were sitting at the bar impatiently waiting. It was ridiculous. And that wasn't the first time. Even when I call in ahead of time, it still takes a pretty damn long time before the food comes out. They either need to work faster or have more workers. If not, they just might see another "accidental" spill of salt on their counter..
author: Steph W.

description:
I am giving it a 5 star rating update.  Not because of the change in the quickness of service (expect to stay in line for quite a while if you go on a nice weekend) but because the owners are my saviors.  
They have bought out the old C & M Bar which was on the corner of 48th and Judah.  Not only was that place a blight on the Sunset, but they played really bad music at 4 in the morning (when bars should be closed).  From the job card, they will continue to have the Beer and Spirit license that was given to the property.
I really hope they make it into a place with a nice little bar and a TV or two which will play Giants games.  I try to go to the one down the block, but with only 4 or 5 barstools, it gets a little crowded.
I have been unable to find out when this new place will open, but I hope that it will be soon.  I haven't seen the inside, but they have been working on it almost non-stop since they bought it.  Renovations are nice, but them opening would be fantastic.
author: Shawn B.

description: Good coffee, beer on tap, can't beat the locale
author: Kevin K.

description:
Great coffee.  Great sandwiches.  Great people.  

When the sun is out in SF, it is a very comfortable place to spend the day.  

I will be back for sure.
author: Wesley B.

description: Wow, what a find at the end of the N-Judah line.  I was trying to get to Cowgirl Creamery at Point Reyes, but the traffic to get across the bridge was god awful that day, so I gave up and decided to try going to Ocean Beach and happened upon this little joint that was packed with happy people and happy dogs.  I figured it had to be good.  The menu is pretty standard for a coffee/sandwich place, nothing too fancy, but what they do they do really well.  One really  nice point was the variety of breads that they have.  I really can't stand when places charge you an arm and a leg for a sandwich and serve it to you on oroweat.  One bad thing was the wait.  There's not a lot of room inside, and so you end up fighting with like ten people waiting for their food at the counter.  But I'd definitely go back on a nice day.
author: Ash T.

description: Stumbled upon this as a stray surfer from London on Sunday morning after being drawn to the area by Mollusk surf shop nearby.  As an Aussie I'm not easily pleased when it comes to coffee, but found the bean to be excellent here.  Also, loved the vibe - super chilled even though it filled up quickly given it was a Sunday.  Great local option.
author: Andy Y.

description: Love this place. Perfect for after a romantic stroll on the beach or a morning surf. Local charm, free wifi, and great coffee (made exactly how you want it w/o the attitude). They also do food and alcohol which I've never partook in.
author: Ravenna P.

description:
My latest San Francisco coffee shop discovery! 

This cafe is right across from Ocean Beach and makes for a lovely pre- or post- stop. The coffee is organic (and well-made!). There is ample seating. Yummy bagels. A bar with multiple beers on tap! A very friendly atmosphere...  this place has pretty much everything I like about a coffee shop (and lots more).
author: Kimi W.

description:
A girlfriend and I recently stopped by Java Beach for some sandwiches and a beer...by stopping by I mean we stayed there for at least 3 hours. We were supposed to be having a "quick lunch date" but the pitcher of Stella helped to extend our stay.

Pro's: Sunny seats outside
           Pitchers of beer
           yummy sandwiches
           cute dogs and surfers
           great service
           pastries!

Con's: can't think of any...except that it's not near my house
author: Zoe W.

description:
Here's my two cents:

They let us make change for the muni!  I feel like so many places won't do that.  But good ol' Java Beach, hooked us up!
author: Levi B.

description:
After spending almost three hours volunteering out in the cold in Golden Gate Park today, the only thing that I wanted to defrost my tired, frozen body was a hot sub sandwich and a steaming cup of chai from Java Beach. It was exactly what I needed... like a much needed hug from an old friend. 

I ordered a medium Tsunami - mortadella, ham, and salami piled on a  fresh toasted roll. I got mine with pepperjack cheese and jalapeno peppers and all the standard fixings. This was complemented by a cup of sweetened chai. It had just the right amount of sweetness.

Staff is very courteous and friendly. My drink order got mixed up with someone elses, and they happily made me another one. Highly recommend this place.
author: Monica N.

description:
The turkey sandwich is super tasty and nicely toasted, and even though I only got a small size, it definitely filled me up. Only downfall in my opinion was that it took 20 min or so to get our sandwiches after ordering (and it was a pretty empty night). Other than that, it was good. 

There was a musician there entertaining us with some songs, although it could be a bit awkward at times when you're the only person in the audience. 

The location is great (near the beach at the end of the N outbound line) and the food is nice. Plus it's priced much like a Togo's sandwich, but better.
author: Yosie G.

description:
Talk about a line. I mean, it's not long, it just takes a while to get through it. I've been here on multiple weekends just before running off to various things out near Ocean Beach/Zoo and they always have a good selection of coffee, pastries, and simple sandwiches. They get busy. There's not a lot of seating. And their little outdoor section is wonderful but kinda small. Parking is fairly easy down the block and it's right next to the beach access.

I wouldn't go here to hang out so much as to get something before walking along the cool sea wall.

Times visited: 4+
author: Amy L.

description:
Their sandwiches are amazing and it's all about the bread.  I recommend the Tsunami or the vegetarian. 

The bread is so good that we've been known to go and buy just the bread and take it home.

If you don't want a sandwich, pour your coffee on the bread and eat it. 

It really is that good. 

Other than the bread, the atmosphere is relaxing and quaint. They sell decent beer and serve decent coffee. 

If you sit outside, you'll see some local wackos, but I'm pretty sure that they are harmless.  Maybe.
author: Kim S.

description:
the service is always friendly and fast, and they have a great variety of drinks and pastries, sandwiches, etc.  if you come at a busy time, there is a line out the door for service.  

no fifth star yet..but i always come here and recommend it to people.
author: asia c.

description: value for money ... the java club sandwich was worth every penny. the only problem with this place is that it doesn't have a lot of space and the people who come here hold on to the tables forever.
author: S C.

description: Love the coffee !!! Consistently enjoyable Americano!!! Same price for 1-3 shots of espresso!  Bagels are delicious! = D
author: Mrs. Dawn H.

description:
The OB sandwich (for Ocean Beach) was delicious and large enough to share.  We had ours made out of pastrami and swiss cheese, the bread was hot and crunchy but soft in the middle.  They divided in to two baskets and gave us lots of chips.

Crowded and a bit pricy, but the location is great and the coffee decent.  I'll go again.
author: Brenda B.

description: Good Coffee... But more than that? Good people. And when I say good people, I don't limit that to the staff. I found that the patronage and staff alike, were very kind and friendly. It's hard to find a place that is so douche-free in California. Hats off to Java Beach!
author: Sam N.

description:
Minus two stars for the slightly overpriced everything but one star added back to that for the great atmosphere and the remodel that they did several months ago. This place is good, it never has disappointed me, but its still just a little cafe with basic drinks, sandwiches, salads, and pastries. The location is very cool and there are always lots of fun and interesting people to meet, which is my only reason for ever going. Oh, another big bonus is the free wifi which definitely makes it a better place to just hang. 
My big complaint is that its just plain overpriced. Not way overpriced but everything is just a bit more than you would expect to pay. Basically, a drink you would think should be like $3 is $4.25 or a pastry you would think should be $1 is $2... that kind of overpriced-- just enough so you are still willing to buy it but more than its worth and enough that it makes me not want to go as often as I would really like to.
author: Christina M.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco for 7 years now, and this is easily one of my top 5 favorite places here. Everything about this place is just so amazing its unfair. The cafe is right across the street from the beach. The cafe is always very warm and cozy. There is a very comfortable couch to relax, study, read, etc. on. The food is excellent... all of it. Delicious, generously sized pastries and bagels. The sandwhiches are the best I have found in SF. Coffee drinks are above average, and they get mad props for allowing you to choose between 1 and 4 shots of espresso in your drink wtihout charging you extra. There is also beer and wine served at a very small bar area. The selection of alcohol is pretty good. The service here has been consistently awesome, even when the line has been backed up for half a block during busy events such as bay to breakers. Everyone always makes sure you order what you really want and works really, really fast to make it for you. The cashier will always greet you with a smile. I went here after bay to breakers once, and not only was there much champagne and beer to be had with other runners, but there were two musicians from somewhere in African (too drunk to remember specifically where) that were playing these rad drum string instrument things that they had made themselves. They were there playing for like 4 hours... it was hella fun. I recently moved to the Sunset, and I visit this place often, as should you all. Every one of ya. Java Beach is just a damn good place to get food by the beach.

I  moved to the Sunset, and I am addicted to this place, hardcore. I don't think a week has gone by without me making my way down here. Continuously excellent service, food, and of course, the beach.
author: Alexander W.

description: One of my favorite SF Cafe's, great coffee, great atmosphere, great service and great wi-fi. Only reason it's a four in my books is because they don't serve bacon, just can't give a cafe a 5 if I can't have bacon with my breakfast.
author: Rick L.

description:
Alas, my first review. I am going to do things a bit different. 3 word reviews.
I love the long reviews but won't ever write any if I feel like I have to post a book every time I do one of these things. 

Main three things I will probably rate (for future reference):

Location, People, Edible Stuff.

Awesome, Cool, Damn Good (especially their veggie sandwich).

Big thanks to becca for showin me this place  ;)
author: G P.

description:
Location is why we end up here every so often.  Thoughts of coffee, sweets, a book in the warm cafe, then walk by the ocean - sounds like a good dreamy Sunday when you're laying in bed trying to get up.  

But then we get there - always so busy inside its a fight for space, reading becomes a chore as you guard your croissant from the swarms of fat black flies from who knows where, relaxing gets harder as you try to ignore the oddly annoying conversations next to you, and then the coffee orders (which are called out by what they are - e.g., "capucino") become a bit of a push and pull around the bar because that dimwit who was in line behind you grabs for your "capucino".  

The food and coffee is ok.  The croissant is great.  The green tea is just Twinnings and scorching hot.
author: Today Y.

description:
Not a great place to study because it's too loud.  There weren't any seats when I went there at 9pm on a Sunday night.  It is also incredibly chilly if you sit outside.  Don't forget to bring a heavy coat if you come here.

However, i think this is a cute place to meet after the beach or if you just want to sit outside and look a the Sunset.  It's good for shooting the breeze and just chilling with friends.  

Bring a jacket. . .
author: Katie L.

description:
I have been here twice, once  on my way home from school because I had a low blood sugar attack and second on my way to Surf Camp for Kids with Diabetes. Both times were pleasant and quick. They seem to have a lot to offer for such a small place and I thoroughly enjoy their out door seating.
Cards are accepted but there is a $10 minimum. And groups of 4 or less are good because as I have said its kind of a small place.
author: K W.

description:
"Hey hey hey I know! Let's go to the beach!!!!"

"Yeah, yeah, ok, let's go swimming!"

FYI: beaches in San Francisco are cold. And not good for swimming.

That's what Java Beach is there.  To duck inside when the wind threatens to blow you over (or at least destroy your hairstyle).  When you'd rather sit on a comfy leather couch drinking chai and talking over  how fun the beach is and how glad you are you rode the N line all the way out here than actually go the extra block to the beach.
author: Maia B.

description:
It was cold, overcast, and windy on my first visit to Java Beach.  Some friends and I stopped in to grab a coffee, and I was completely impressed.  It's a little outpost right at the end of the BART line, but it has tons of character, and is full of a huge range of people.  

I came back when it was warm and had a couple beers and a sandwich on the patio.  This time it was great for completely different reasons.  In the cold it's a great place to hide, but on a warm summer day it's the most inexpensive luxury you can find near the beach.
author: Kris H.

description:
Ding Dong
End of the line folks,

Right at the end of the N-Judah line lies Java beach..
What a location!
The sound of the waves, the fresh air.
It feels like your in the middle of nowhere

Free wifi....
Nice atmosphere
Good food
Good drinks

It is a spot that I must return to. And then it may get 5 stars..

(did i mention they have warm cider?? mmmm)
author: Dave L.

description: Get the oatmeal!!! great to go, but larger portions if you eat in... Awesome assortment of pastries, I want to eat all of them.  Good variety of coffees too... You're bound to find something you like here...   They have a bar with beers on tap and a happy hour too, but I've only been here for breakfast so far...
author: Bobby P.

description: I've been to Java Beach several times since my initial review, and I have to say I must have hit them on a bad day. To clarify, the employees have been great every time I've been to Java Beach, and maybe it just isn't a condusive place for me to study because of the busyness of the place. In subsequent visits, the coffee has been good, and the atmosphere/crowds have been fine. It's a great place to stop for a cup of coffee after a walk (which I've been doing regularly). Also, I happened to talk to the owner, and she mentioned that the BLT is a work in progress, which makes me feel reassured about Java Beach's goals as a business. 4 stars because of subsequent pleasant visits. Less 1 star because it's so crowded and difficult to find seating if you want to stay a while.
author: Adriana A.

description: I know it's good when I can smell fresh coffee and food from a block away
author: Ari T.

description: I'd give it four stars if it weren't so crowded all the time. I've had their white mocha and their peppermint white mocha. The first time I got the peppermint mocha at late night it was amazing but the next time I got it, it didn't taste as good (it was still pretty good, but not AS good). The bagel's are really good too. Great place for breakfast, not so great for studying. It is really nice if you want to walk on the beach afterwards though.
author: Robin J.

description:
Good Coffee
Open by 5:30
Coffee BEFORE I get on the N in the morning

But really, beside the good coffee and the fun people watching the toasted sandwiches really are my favorite thing about this place. They are REALLY F'en good!!! Really I mean try the "Toasted Tsunami" Really really good on the crunchy toasted bread toasted wonderful goodness...
author: Dustin H.

description:
Me likey.  Tasty coffee and sandwiches and dog butts my dog likes to sniff.  Brother Macguire, you are a SF favorite.

What's up with that Tsunami?  You put crack in there? Me LIIIIIIKE!!

Great place to kick sand outta your shoes and enjoy the nippy ocean breeze.
author: Sheila G.

description:
I love this place! My friend and I found this place on Yelp after deciding we wanted to get out of Berkeley for a day of studying before finals. 

Java Beach Cafe is right across from Ocean Beach at the end of the N-Judah Muni line.  Street parking is easy to find, too, if you prefer driving as opposed to public transit. It's crowded (especially when the Muni comes) but this cafe is really quaint with outdoor seating and friendly customers.  Also, they have FREE wi-fi with a whole strip of electrical outlets lining the walls so you're computer will never run out of juice!  

A local suggested we try their Hot Subs. So, my friend and I split a large hot Tsunami sub (ham, mortadella, salami, melted cheese & special sauce) with "The Works" (pepperoncinis, pickles, and jalapenos). Also, I had a delicious large Carmel Latte.

Bring cash if you only plan on ordering a drink because they have a $10 minimum on cards (note: they do have an ATM in the establishment)
author: Anna R.

description:
Java Beach deserves to have its upsides recognized: neat neighborhood-hangout atmosphere, good people-watching most of the time, both Stella Artois and Guinness on tap, and excellent sandwiches.

However, and this is a big "however", their espresso drinks are plain and blah.  I'm admittedly very picky about foam and espresso, but with Trouble a short walk up Judah, why would I or anyone else settle for bitter espresso and chunky, bubbly foam?
author: Kyle L.

description: One of my favorite places in the world... the other one being Java Beach by the zoo.  Sandwiches are soooooo good, worth the price, always fresh. My favorite place for the brew and chips as well when i need some time to chill. Wonderful people who work there, always cheerful and always cool. I wish this place was bigger so more people can fit.
author: Emir T.

description: Greatly enjoyed the coffee, sandwiches, breakfast, and beer at Java Beach Cafe. Stayed in the motel next door on my recent trip to SF. JBC was a pleasant surprise and turned out to be a highlight of the location for me. Staff is friendly and helpful. Great place to hang out. Will definitely go back.
author: Chuck D.

description:
Beach Java is like Mecca to me. Unlike Starbucks or any other mainstream coffee chains, this place is sacred. Aside from all the great memories I have garnered at this place, the food and the beverages are great. There are so many brews of coffee that I spent a good 30 seconds deciding what to get. The baked goods and sandwiches are great, but they are a little pricey.

The atmosphere is what I really value in this place. The shop has this surfer and bohemian feel to it. There's a big couch where strangers are perfectly comfortable sitting next to each other. There are tables outside if you prefer to take in the mist from the ocean which is only steps away. I also like how local performers come here to perform once in awhile. 

Overall, if you want to escape the monotony of going to Starbucks to enjoy your coffee, this is the place to go.
author: Hilland C.

description: Cool place to hang out. More for discussion than for reading. The place is fairly active. Musicians play their music here all the time. Outdoor seating is available. The location is good too. It's a neighborhood place away from the craziness of the city. Note though that it is at the end of a Muni stop, not that it would bother anybody.
author: Brian Q.

description: Awesome food, awesome people, awesome location. Sure Im a little biased cause I used to work here but still. Its always crazy busy and for very good reason
author: Kalen F.

description: I can not comment on coffee since I don't drink it, but...I love Java Beach! The location is awesome and reminds me of the days when I was a kid living out in that area. A perfect place to grab a sandwich before you roll over to Ocean Beach on a warm city day..or grab a hot cocoa to warm up on the typical SF day at the beach. Dog friendly, cozy, and friendly staff!
author: Drew A.

description: Location is unbeatable on a sunny day! just grab a coffee and go to the beach to relax and/or watch surfers. Coffee was not the best but pretty decent never the less
author: Michael V.

description:
Java Beach is a San Francisco Institution. A true mom and pop cafe. An essential part of my San Francisco tour for out of town guests. I've been going here for a decade strong and I can honestly say each year the menu gets better.  The people watching here is most always entertaining, post up in the seats out front and you will see all walks of life interacting. The best part is it's all happening steps away from the Pacific Ocean.

I will gladly traverse the city with low blood sugar to take down one of their hot subs. Super high quality bread, secret sauce, and the pizza oven bring this sandwich home. I crave them in my bones. As a new mom I've fallen hard back into the caffeine realm. I've relied heavily on their espresso to function these last few months. At the very top of my list is their lattes. Silky smooth with no bitter after taste. Essential!
author: Deirdre O.

description: I travel light daily on the N line which boards at the cafe. I catch the 5:40 and Java opens at 5:30-perfect timing. I was standing outside the Cafe at 5:32 when a staff person came out to dispose of cardboard. I greeted her with  a Good Morning to which she replied curtly Not Yet. I know well the routine that the door is locked open and music is on. She could have said good morning or maybe a smile with the words will be open in a minute. I walked away and spent my $ elsewhere.
author: Larry S.

description:
The coffee is awesome, and some are the snacks. I suggest the chocolate croissant and the carrot cake. 

The fact that I can get drunk at this coffee shop is a definite bonus.
author: Isaac S.

description:
I freakin looove this place! I come here to read, do some writing, or simply just to people watch. They have this outdoor seating thats  perfect for when the weather is nice and warm and the beach is just across the street! 
Great sandwiches and drinks, but the staff definitely could smile more often.
author: Rose B.

description:
OK all of my first few reviews have been all of my favorite places.
Anyway this is one of the best places for a Match.com/Craigslist/lavalife etc blind date in the city as it is reachable by both Muni (the N Judah ends there) and easy street parking (watch the street cleaning signs)
Great coffee, couches, sandwiches, people, dogs etc...
author: Marcus R.

description:
First off, I give it to these folks because they are a no-nonsense joint.  Maybe its the Irish influence, but the ladies who work there really are sensitive to the folks at the back of the line... "next in line please!!"  Even when it gets crowded, I hardly ever have had to wait more than just a few mins for my morning fix.  I usually go for the 'columbian supreme' and have never been disappointed... 'bernies blend' is a good runner-up.  

Also worth mentioning is that they have great hot turkey subs and very cold beers.
author: John T.

description:
One of my all time favorite cafes is SF. I often go here to study or read. The service is good, sometimes a little slow, but this can be attributed to the high volume of customers, and thus the continuous stack of orders. The walls are decorated with wonderful modern pictures of surfers and beach scenes (also for sale!) 

There is a surprising number of seats for the limited space. Sometimes I have to wait a few minutes for something to open up, or share a table, but I usually get snuggled into a decent spot before my order is up. They have the option of bar seating, couches, single tables, party tables, and tables and benches outside. 

I love the proximity to the beach and the paved path along Ocean Beach. I often ride my beach cruiser here, just because I can. Note: riding a three speed cruiser around SF is not generally recommended. 

The cafe has long hours, beer, many different food options, fresh baked goods, specialty items, vegan and veg options, good prices, and great tasting coffee. 

The main downside is the changing temperatures. It would be unfair to blame the cafe, being that they are right on the beach and can't stop the fog from rolling in :)
author: Jean P.

description: Java bitch, you mean! We don't go here anymore. The service is horrible.
author: Patrick S.

description: This is a great place to get some food after walking on the beach.  The service was great and the food was really good.  Sandwiches are big and filling.  Definitely stop by if you're hungry in the neighborhood.
author: Michael L.

description:
Very cool outdoor option, sitting on the end of the N-line train, where it sits in a crescent moon, waiting for the trip back up. Ocean Beach calls just over the burm, and the coffee's good, too.

A chocolate chocolate chip muffin with a bear claw and a double latte, a rare sunny afternoon, and plenty of dogs to laugh at. 

What more do you want?
author: Jesse B.

description:
I'll give Java Beach 4 stars for what is generally a 3 star experience, because it's a decent, reliable place.

Anyone who has been here on a day when it isn't raining knows that Java Beach can be very, very busy. It is pretty much the only option for coffee and food for several blocks. A new pack of customers shows up every 7-15 minutes as the N opens its doors almost directly into the shop. There's free Internet but you may not be able to find a seat to use it.

The coffee drinks are unremarkable but okay. The *sandwiches*, though, are yummy. I don't know where they get their bread but it's absolutely awesome, especially after it is warmed in the oven. Seriously, it is the BEST SANDWICH BREAD in town if you like it warm and crusty. You can smell it half a block down the street. I'm getting hungry just writing about it. But the flip side is that the staff is pathologically unable to get sandwich orders right. They ask you what you don't want rather than what you do; this seems to confuse them just as much as it does customers. Still, once you have your tuna melt with the right stuff on it, it's awesome.

I don't have any problems recommending Java Beach. Mostly what's wrong with it is that it is so busy, and most people in the restaurant business think that's good.
author: Joseph H.

description:
It's a cute coffee shop. They have free trade coffee. 

That said I used to go there about 3X a week to get a cup of coffee. Only one cup of coffee. 

My biggest gripe about the place? It's the wait to order. The place has two cash registers and I've counted as many as 5 workers. EVEN if the line is only 4 people long it takes a RIDICULOUS amount of time to order ONE cup of coffee. OH and I've timed it... I have waited as long as 20 minutes to order a cup of coffee. Usually the wait is 15 minutes. And it's not like they pour it for you or brew it on the spot. They hand you a cup and you go to a thermos and get it yourself. Seriously how hard can it be to take my money and hand me a cup? Why do I have to wait 15-20 minutes to be handed a cup? In a line of only 5 people? 

It's unbelievable how inefficient and slow they are. I've been there dozens of times and it's always the same. Now I avoid going there if I actually have to be somewhere that day. You can miss two Muni trains in a row just trying to order a cup of coffee.
author: Art L.

description:
I was born and raised in SF, discovered this place while in college, and have been going here since! I moved down the peninsula but I still make the trip up to SF for the sole purpose of getting a large latte with soy milk, two shots of espresso. I cannot express how good the coffee here is. I am not sure about the food, I did grab a sub one time and it too was really good, but Im just writing about the coffee, as I am kind of a coffee-holic. The people are cool too! I am not a big fan of hipsters but these java beach coffee hipsters are awesome, probably because all of them know how to make good coffee. 

I RECOMMEND THIS PLACE TO ANYONE IN THE SF AREA!
author: Jane D.

description: There's a couch in there that I like to plop down on.  Good coffee and sweets.  When the N-Judah unloads ,it gets crowded.
author: Bleep S.

description: the tsunami is seriously tasty. french bread, toasted, loaded with deliciousness.
author: Abigail W.

description: My local coffee shop. Number one reason I like this place is the Agave Nectar. I'm over sugar, and this stuff is expensive, so totally rad they have it, and keep it stocked. The drip coffee is great, and I hate drip, so are the sandwiches. Line gets out the door, prices are steepish, cashier I have no complaints, but no raves either, and they call their Americano's "Muddy Water". They serve booze, but I prefer to drink that at an establishment that specializes in it.
author: Dave J.

description:
Great place to sit outside and enjoy a cup of coffee.

Beer, wine and sandwiches too!

Don't let the long line intimidate you, it moves quickly.

The staff is always pleasant. Always is a strong word, I'm  just saying they're good people. 

I'm looking forward to the Sloat location opening.
author: alisha b.

description:
** Attention Owners **

We'd love to come more often... if only there were a table available. Surely it can't be good for your business to give up all of your table for an hour or two to laptop users sipping a sole coffee...
author: Paulo M.

description: The last authentic San Franciscan coffee shop. I feel honored to support this small, local business.
author: N I.

description: I really enjoy coming to this place. The atmosphere is great and the people are friendly. I don't mind this, but the lines usually seem quite long, but they get through them fast considering their size. The sandwiches are amazing... try the dutch crunch bread.
author: Paul B.

description: Good location, soft and hard seating (though the couches have seen better days) friendly service, can be a little noisy with pick up orders being called out a high volume.  Nice to have options of soy, almond, and rice milk for those who eschew the cow udder products.  Good vegan cookies, several to choose from.
author: Bob G.

description: Got a blackberry Italian soda after a long walk to the beach.  This place was hopping.  The sandwiches looked spectacular.  Wish I tried more.
author: Megan P.

description:
Walking on the beach and feel a bit of that ocean air chill.  Ahhh then you realize that you are close to Judah street and yessss...there is a cafe just a hop skip and jump away.

Java beach is  a great place to get a coffee drink, tea even a beer.   Hang out either indoors on the couch or outside getting a bit of sun.  Across the street is a lovely sidewalk garden where you can sometimes find a few guitarist playing or practicing........

Just a good place to get a coffee treat....Forget St*@B^@Ks.
author: Edessa C.

description:
The worst thing about this place is where the coffee cup lids are located.  I hate having to reach around people to get one when it's crowded.  It's wierd asking someone to grab one for me cuz then my mouth has to go where some stranger's hand touched my coffee cup lid.  
 
I really like their large pastrami sandwiches though - definitely worth a try.
author: Roger P.

description: This is one of my most favorite cafes in the Sunset. I especially love to come here on nice, sunny days, but so does everyone else so it's always pretty crowded. Sometimes they make a couple mistakes on orders and I don't even say anything and just take whatever they give me because it can get pretty crazy in there, but they are always very nice about it when you do tell them. But I love it cuz it's such a cute place, with good coffee, food, and even beer on tap! I've walked by at night once and I think they even had some kind of open mic. Ever since Canvas Cafe closed on 9th and Lincoln, I have been searching for a hole-in-the-wall cafe that has a laid back feel where I can just kick it on some comfy couches w/some friends or a book. I think this is the one for me...
author: Emy s.

description:
Definitely a nice place with the right combination - ocean beach, internet, bar/cafe, and food.

People are friendly, but most of the time i went seems very crowded. Make sure you bring a jacket cause ocean beach can be cold.

Want to hang out?
author: Baz T.

description: Oh i order a sandwich 9/9/12 and gave a one dollar tip on credit card around 11:38am. I waited 30 minutes and no sandwich. I asked for a refund  because i could not wait any longer. When they gave my refund, they did not want to give the one dollar tip on the credit card. I had to scream to cashier that i wanted to talk to manager. Oh she gave me the dollar with saying it from my personal money. Those folks are crazy. They still expect  to keep a dollar tip when they could not provide the sandwich.
author: Stanley L.

description: I came to this place today with my friends. We were at the beach and wanted to go to a nearby cafe to relax and chit chat. Parking here was pretty easy. We found parking directly across the street. The cafe wasn't too big. There was plenty of seating inside and outside the store. Because of our group size of 7, we had to squeeze into a small booth. My friend and I shared the BLT sandwich. What was strange was none of the employees called our order or a name when our food was ready so we waited several minutes and guessed when our food was ready. The same happened to my other friend who ordered a sandwich. The ambiance of the store was alright. It was cozy but it felt old. The flow of the store was weird. It felt cramped. The store was dirty. When we got there, there were dirty tables. When we left, there were dirty tables. If I lived around the area or came to the area often, I wouldn't visit this place frequently.
author: Kayla V.

description: This place has a very wide selection of coffee options. I also like the seasonal variety with eggnog, mint, pumpkin etc. During peak hours, finding a seat could be a problem, but you can always take it a few blocks down and sit and watch the ocean... Ahhh that's the stuff....
author: David S.

description: My large double latte was the best thing about this place and it was overpriced. The barista working the cashier was kind of pretentious and assumed I knew exactly how they 'did' coffee. Most places have a set number of shots that come in the sized latte you order. Here apparently you can get any number of shots in any size though. So I could order a 1 shot super-extra-large latte? What on earth is the point of that? Anyways, I'm going with 2 stars b/c the latte itself tasted good and did it's job. But I don't see myself rushing back here.
author: Todd F.

description: My ultimate study cafe. If this cafe disappears I will never graduate from San Francisco State University. This cafe is like an essential organ for me. I just can't do it. Recently, I have been biking from 9th every weekend. Reasonable prices and great sandwiches. Internet and power plugs, the whole shebang. Always noisy, crowded, friendly, and hot. Loooooove it!!!!
author: Al A.

description: Where to pee near Ocean Beach?  I tried the restroom at the gas station on the corner of Lincoln & Great America Hwy - the surly gas attendant dude said that it was open and didn't require a key.  I tried it several times, but the door just jiggled and wouldn't open completely.  I had the feeling someone was doing a Pursuit of Happyness and camping out there because no one was coming out.  I made a quick jaunt to the divey Thai restaurant across the street, disregarding their no public restrooms sign.  After all, it was New Year's Day, a holiday, and wouldn't they waive this requirement just this once since I was in dire need and nice about it?  I tried the door of their bathroom, but of course, it was locked.  I asked the waitress for the key, she simply smiled apologetically and said I would gain no access to the restroom.  I said even if it's an emergency? She nodded her head still no.  I remembered the Java Beach Cafe two blocks down.  It was packed inside, with a line of folks out the door.  I went in with a purpose, straight to the bathroom all the way in the back left corner. Hooray - the door was unlocked, bathroom was clean, no hassle, no fuss = heaven!  I like this place not just cuz they have bathrooms, but cuz it's a great local hangout - a place to go on a lazy weekend morning.  Our running group often heads here after a run along Ocean Beach for food and to commiserate about life.  They've got some solid comfort food - like bagels, croissants, peasant pies, etc.  I usually opt for one of their sandwiches, salads, or soups. As per the usual, there was a line nonstop out the door for the entire morning.   When it's crowded, you're eavesdropping on conversations, conversing with strangers, sharing newspapers, etc. -- one big neighborhood morning together.
author: Peg S.

description: Walked in and out for a quick tea. But the place I had a very good first impression on the place.  There was a live one man band, a small bar in the back, and the tea was pretty good. And it's right by the beach.  Will definitely go back next time I am in the area.
author: U U.

description: I love java beach...their iced mochas are insanely delicious...and is a wonderful treat to have every once in awhile. they have great sandwiches too. they have a great atmosphere for relaxing and hanging out with friends. its close proximity to the beach is another bonus in my book.
author: caroline g.

description: On warm, fog-free summer days, I like to hike the two-mile long pedestrian path/bicycle trail that meanders along the Great Highway just south of Golden Gate Park. On the return trip, I'll usually stop here to rest my feet and treat my palate to a cold drink or a strong cup of joe and a slice of heavenly carrot cake. It's easy to justify the splurge when I know I can work it off by walking the final mile at a very brisk pace.
author: Gourmet G.

description: The best place to pick up a sandwich to take to the beach or to retreat to from the beach on a windy day. Lots of beer on tap, great coffee, tasty food. A really nice seating arrangement inside and lots of tables to soak up the sun in.
author: Allison K.

description: I really like that it is loud and everyone else is fine with that!  I really can't stand the whispering coffee joints that cause for everyone to put their full attention on you for laughing out loud.  My only complaint is that the pitchers of beer were very over priced & when it was happy hour they wanted you to be excited with them that the pitchers where now the normal/more acceptable price.  I see myself heading back there sooner or later.  Lower the price on the pitchers and I'll b sure to be there damn near every Sunday!
author: Nick M.

description: A funky, beachy environment with an even funkier clientele--from sunset neo-hippies, to homeless people hanging outside, to surfers, or contractors grabbing a cup of coffeee on their way to a job.  They have a praticularly uncomfortable sofa that has seen way too many bodies in it, and a staff that some days can be selectively surly--maybe they're just too busy. The coffee is decent & I like their bagel loaded with hummus. BUT, they've recently instated a new, 'no refills' policy on their regular coffee, which at first ruffled the feathers of my coffee junkiness, but now I see it as just another reason to drink espresso instead--or go without. A decent place--I like it, but don't love it--especially if you want people watching with your coffee.
author: N B.

description: Cozy, always packed. The food is really tasty. It's really nice to sit outside on a sunny day and enjoy the experiance of Java Beach Cafe.  I like the happy hour here too!
author: Sonya D.

description: Very affordable and definitely the best chicken sandwich I've had. Dog friendly too
author: Alan W.

description:
I didn't immediately love this place. It was too crowded to really love it. But, the second time I went I actually scored a table and was able to camp out for awhile.  This gave me time to really take in the cafe.  

What's awesome is that although it was constantly busy and crowded, I could still hear the people I was talking with.  We all got food, and everyone's sandwiches looked great.  I went with the Mozzarella/Tomato/Pesto sandwich and ended up with what looked like four mini open faced sandwiches--delish.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
update: two days later and I have to take away a star. when these guys are really busy they might not pay attention to details. Like, I asked for a Carmel Latte,and they give me a Mocha. I don't usually look at my receipt to make sure they get my order right, and I drank it anyhow (twas good, but not really a carmel late). My friend ordered tomato on her bagel , and it was on the receipt, but failed to show up on the bagel.  Granted the line was out the door for most of the morning, but um, accuracy is needed for five stars.
author: Anna O.

description: Second best sandwich in the city (sorry, Yellow Sub remains King of the San Francisco Sandwich). Tasty hot subs can be made with the "works" which includes jalepenos AND peperoncinis!! Messy and satisfying. Wait can be a bit (longer I think if you aren't a regular). Bonus points for the fact that you can have a pint while you wait for your sub!
author: Jessa B.

description:
I used to go here a lot when I lived on LaPlaya (not that I'm much farther now, but...) for coffee in the morning before catching the N at the end of the line.  The coffee is nothing to scream about- although it is all fair trade (and organic? not sure).  Since it's like a row of pumps to choose from, I like to mix the house blend with hazelnut. They have food on the menu for breakfast and lunch and their bagels pack a LOT of cream cheese.  I normally would scrape most of it off.  
One time I saw this guy go for a warm-up and the chick behind the counter got really angry.  I guess there are no go-backs or something here... well, he tried to pay her whatever change his warm-up cost (since it wasn't a whole cup) and she was like, no, pay the full amout for a cup.  They went back and forth a couple of times, because clearly egos were at stake here, and finally he dropped his change on the counter and left.  Not a pleasant scene in the morning.
I still go by here- not for the atmosphere (a bit too... yuppie?  older, richer crowd on their break from the stresses of the big city?  not sure...)-  but because it's convenient and a nice little walk.
author: Allison G.

description: Definitely a good place to hang out, eat, do some work, or simply just chat. Their sandwiches are tasty and super big. I love how they put soo much jalapenos and pepperchinis. Luckily im fortunate enough to live just two blocks away. Im in there about three times a week and the only thing i despise is waiting twenty min + for my sandwiches. If there were half stars in the rating board and i would honestly rate this place 3 1/2.
author: bella h.

description: When I'm out of coffee at home, I run to java beach to get their regular small coffee, when I have no quarters for laundry, I run to java beach and pretend I need coins for the N judah, when I'm hungry in the morning and I have no food, I go to java beach to eat their turkey croissant or ham n cheese croissant.  The place smells like a bunch of guys just waking up in the morning, I mean it is stinky morning breath, the gals that works there probably are having PMS 24/7 but hey I live in the neighborhood, so I give 'em 3 stars for having the closest coffee shop from my place
author: Albert W.

description: Neat spot right on the edge of Judah, so it's highly accessible. Across from the ocean, so always a good vibe. They're always busy, sometimes the tables aren't wiped down as often as customers leave, but they're always nice to oblige once asked.
author: Jay K.

description: I'm comparing this to place to "Simple Pleasures" as it's the other option I have for local coffee house/cafe ... Better selection of coffee, better sandwiches, better places to sit (including more outdoor spots), free Internet  (Simple Pleasures charges $5 a day) and better looking females (to distract me from getting any work done, of course) ... This is now my work-from-home spot.
author: Tom P.

description: When I asked for a small coffee, they mean a small coffee.  Finished it in 6 slurps.  And when they said medium sandwich will fill you up, just eating half of it filled me up.  I'm not trying to be Goldilocks here, but portion sizes aren't exactly accurate here for some reason. Place is cool.  All the way out by Ocean Beach.  A line starts forming out the door from time to time.  Coffee was decent, but nothing to go bananas over.  Sandwich had the fixings: pickles, peppers, onions and more.  I wouldn't say that this place was amazing honestly.  I think I've had better service at a Starbucks than here.  Perhaps its because this place is more laid back, so everything seems a little slower over here.  Or perhaps its one of the only cafes near by, along a scenic route, that we're actually paying for the view and not the quality/service.  Hmm (think Beach Chalot).  Finally, if you use the restroom and think, where is the lock.  Um, I can't pee if there isn't a lock.  Look up the door higher. Some genius whose over 6 feet probably put that sucker in.  Then read some of the wall writings and comics on the bathroom wall too.  Always charming for a little seaside cafe.
author: Janice F.

description: I really like this place, close to the beach, next to the N line stop, close to my house, free WI-Fi.. good beers on tap.  I'm not a coffee drinker but the tea i had was good.  Plus they have good little snacks=)
author: Megan L.

description: This cafe epitomizes the uniquely far-out vibe of the Outer Sunset -- I mean the OUTer Sunset.  Corner spot at the end of the N-Judah line, it's inside and outside seating are pretty chill, the coffee's decent, and just like  Carla D. says, they pour Stella on tap.  It's a good place to relax just about any time of day.
author: Alfonso E.
