description: I only give it 2 stars because it's like almost every other coffee-cafe in the city except it's super crowded with rude servers.  The food is okay but nothing to scream at.  Every time I go, I see strange middle aged guys just sitting around giving dirty looks.
author: Mike M.

description:
Best sandwiches EVER!

I dare you to try a hot turkey sub and tell me otherwise.


This is the kind of great little cafe/coffee shop that every neighborhood needs. They have great sandwiches, great places to chill, and even beer on tap if you are in the mood. Can get a little crowded, but here's a tip: If it's a nice day, escape the crowd jockeying for tables and take your food or your coffee and go sit on the beach.
author: J B.

description:
When my family and I first moved to the neighborhood, we were at Java Beach every morning... But honestly, this place is so-so (if that). 

For starters, there was always a huge line whenever I even attempted to order something there. Secondly, there is never a place to sit. I do understand that if you are looking for wireless internet, there aren't many choices in Outer Sunset, but come on... Just trying to sit down and enjoy a hot chocolate with my two year old was impossible... And I'm sure many of us know how difficult it can be to handle a cranky, hungry two year old. Next, when I finally got to start drinking my hot chocolate, it was only half full (the cup was 12 oz.), and I did NOT indicate that I wanted a kid's hot chocolate. For that, I feel the drink was waayy overpriced. Lastly, service takes forever, and the people behind the counter seem to be on another planet. I work in a coffee shop myself, so I know how hard it can be to deal with a line, but hey... If you can't take the heat, get out of the kitchen. It took an hour to get two sandwhiches!

Anyway, it's not the worst place I've been, after working at Starbucks for eleven months. When you need wireless and you're thirsty and a patient person as well, this is the place for you. Plus it is RIGHT next to the beach, literally a few steps away... But honestly, I'd rather go to Trouble, it's only a few blocks up Judah, has a much more creative atmosphere, awesome people, and their hot chocolate is seriously the best. Def. worth $3.00.
author: Catherine H.

description: Pretty laid back style cafe with some good selection of vegan cookies and good Chai tea! The close proximity to the beach is a big plus as you can hold on to the hot drinks while strolling along the shoreline.
author: T L.

description: Everyone seems to like this place, but the staff just ruins it for me.  The attitude has got to go, lassies.  Yes it's true, it's nice to sit outside and drink beer and apparently their carrot cake is the ISH, but how about a smile? Even a little one?
author: Sarah S.

description: Great location by the ocean - pretty average drinks/food. Not good for working, at least on weekends - it's crowded, noisy (why shout all of the orders?!) and the seating isn't too comfy.
author: Jessica A.

description: I really enjoyed this place. It's located right next to the beach on the corner of La Playa with a charming outdoor seating area and a cozy interior with couches and a bar. The service is great and the employees are very friendly. You can tell it's a local favorite. The sandwiches are fantastic because they are so fresh and made with the best ingredients. The pastries and muffins are good and very fresh and I really like their coffee too, it's fantastic. I kind of wish it was on my way to work so I could stop there more often, but I don't mind heading down to the beach to pick up a good cup of coffee and a nice lunch.
author: Denise S.

description: I've read reviews of this place and it sounded small and cramped but it's actually pretty roomy for a cafe/coffee place. They've got nice over-stuffed couches by the window, bar seating in the back and plenty of outdoor tables with waaayyy too many chairs around them. Turns out they also have live music on some evenings. I was going to give this place 5 stars but at the bottom of my coffee I found chunks of coffee grounds - eeewwwwwww! The ham and cheese croissant was delicious, I like how they just take a regular croissant and do it sandwich style with cheese and ham vs. baked one-piece croissants you find at other places. It's less oily. I'll definitely be back to check out the rest of the menu before a stroll to the beach!
author: Tatyana K.

description:
I actually did not get a chance to try the coffee. I was finishing a run and went in to get a drink. I ordered my drink and handed them my credit card. They informed me that they had a minimum charge of $5 for credit card purchases. I asked them if they were aware of Mastercard's policy prohibiting vendors from requiring a minimum purchase amount, and they were not aware. I refused to buy additional crap to reach the $5 limit so I left. 

Conveniently, they have an ATM in the store. That way they can get customers to take out cash and get charged an ATM fee that is probably more than the coffee that they are buying.
author: Jacob M.

description: I came here after spending the afternoon at Golden Gate Park while visitng San Fran. I desperately needed a warm coffee and stumbled upon Java Beach Cafe. I thought it was absolutely adorable and would be a fun place to get some coffee with friends or read a book. I got a white mocha with 2 shots. And it was DELICIOUS. One of the best coffee drinks i've ever had. Only downside.. it was 3.50 for the tiniest little drink!! But it was worth it. I'd love to come back and try more coffee and some of the food. Its a must if you're in the area.
author: Kim S.

description: How can you not love a cafe next to the beach???  I love this cafe's Tsunami sub sammich.  I like their Caramel Latte and the ambience is so chill and relaxing.
author: Keika L.

description:
I live really close so I come here a lot in the mornings for a cup of coffee or a bagel sandwich.  They have several different types of coffee to choose from (serve yourself) and I'm pretty sure they're all fair-trade coffees. 

Staff are usually friendly and helpful.

My only problem with the place is that it gets really crowded inside and it's often hard to find a seat, especially on cold days when no one wants to sit outside.  Also, service can be really slow when they get busy.  But hey, they've got beer on tap, so just have a drink while you wait!
author: A P.

description: I'd probably come here more often if it weren't so far away. Thinking of their hot sandwiches makes me salivate. Unfortunately, whenever I come here, there's usually a long line and a long wait time which makes me wish they had a better system. If you're only coming for the food and you're impatient like me, your best bet is to call your order in ahead of time.
author: Novi M.

description: Good coffee.  Cool scene.  A block from the beach.  If only there were other things to do nearby...
author: Gina K.

description: 4 stars is for the awesome HOT SUBS and neverending supply of chocolate old fashion doughnuts, for the availability of beer and the cute atmosphere which includes plenty of dog-friendly outdoor space.  If I were rating the coffee alone, maybe 3 stars, for the fact they have a large selection, but the brew is definately not the greatest I've ever had.
author: Jesse Lu S.

description: Java Beach is the beast coffee shop in the sunset by far.  Its open late, has good treats and a bar!  Can't get any better.
author: Justin O.

description: In the 70s this was "Dick's at the Beach" a serviceable bar with jazz at night. I'm glad to see Java Beach here now, it's a good addition. I wonder, if the service is so bad, why is this place always full? Most of my visits are limited to sunny Sunday afternoons, and then there is a constant stream of customers, the line goes from three to ten deep. There basically is no service, just the staff in the weeds for hours on end. If you want someone to kiss your butt, greet you by name and ask if you're having your usual -- I wouldn't go here. But if you want sunny outdoor tables, beer by the pitcher, a full coffee menu and very good subs: join the crowd.
author: jim b.

description: Creepy people and decent coffee. Overall, it isn't a bad coffee house.  The downside is all the stupid fucking yuppies with their fucking brats running around like it was a fucking day care center.  Ugh.  The upside is that their coffee is good as hell.  They close at 11, which is sort of a bust, but then again, almost every coffee house I went to in SF was closed by 11.  Fucking stupid.
author: Sabrina C.

description: This place scores big with location. It's a haven for pedestrians, cyclist, and dog owners who want a quick blast of whatever their pleasure is. They have quality beer, wine, tea, and of course coffee. I go for all three depending whether I am a pedestrian, a cyclist, or a dog owner. Whatever I want at the moment, it's all good. I never eat here and I never stay in. There's a certain scent in the air. I may be trippin' but it smells like brown sugar or something like that. It's cool to chill outside and make conversation. The patrons there are nice and friendly people. The staff here are nice people with no fake enthusiasm like franchise coffee places. You can tell who the regulars are. They wear Java Beach attire. It's actually pretty cool.
author: Butch M.

description:
Have you ever had a feeling of looking for a new place, experience, friend ... only to realize that nothing ... 'compares to you' ... as the song goes?

After months of search, trial and error, disappointments and surprises, I have become to realize how much I love this place. It is not perfect, not always welcoming - how would you react if someone else was sitting in YOUR place? Staff smiles when seeing me and I do not even have to utter my words any more to get what I want, when it is too early to sound sane or voice your needs... I had some best conversations with strangers here. Well, they aren't strangers any more, after they show you their family photos or spend half a day solving the world's problems with you. And they will leave you alone when you need to do that phone conference with Europe at ungodly early hour or rush that project through. And you can just drop everything in the middle of it and get your bottom to the beach really fast, diving into the ocean breeze and enjoying the endless horizon ... My journey reached  its little nirvana ... And latte is good ...
author: Rob R.

description: Yum! Great veggie bagel, not-too-sweet mocha (in fact, excellent) & great coffee (per my coffee-snob husband). When I snuck a lick of the whipped cream on my daughter's hot chocolate, I knew we were at a great place...this was not out of a can! Friendly staff, too. Bonus = free wi-fi.
author: Janet D.

description:
it was january, and it was 72 degrees outside, so we rode our bikes to the beach.

and then this cafe had seats and we were able to grab a beer/coffee/juice and that made us happy.  this place was quite crowded, but they had enough chairs/benches to sit outside and bask in the sun.  seriously, that just deserves a 4 in and of itself.
author: Jason J.

description: Solid latte, service was so-so. They're a little on the slow side here, but the outdoor seating is wonderful and the latte was pretty good. This is a wonderful place to come and chill out.
author: Erik S.

description: I live right next to java and i finally decided to go. The white mocha was rlly good, the sandwiches were full of meat, and the italian soda was very sweet. The service was nice just like any other cafe. The place is very warm, and it was nice to sit inside because it was freezing outside. The only thing is that it is very crowded, and may be hard to find a place to sit.
author: Nikita K.

description: Pretty mediocre spot.  A strip of outlets and free wi-fi is the biggest plus.  Also open later than most places in the neighborhood.  Tea is twinings (blah) though people say the coffee is good.  Basic pastries with salads and sandwiches too.  Place gets crazy on weekends during the day.  Would be better if they didn't yell out every time someone has an order ready.  If someone doesn't come the first time they yell loud enough for people outside to hear.  I assume this system saves them time and money, but definitely makes the vibe less cool than it should be.  More cafeteria than cafe.
author: F U.

description: Went here on a sunny warm day in the afternoon.  What a great place.  Friendly service and good coffee.  I only had a cookie but the food looks good.  It's a very neighborhoody place.  I was dying for a cup of coffee while out enjoying Ocean Beach and area, and my friend recommended this place.  Perfect choice!
author: Billy Dee R.

description: Am I a horrible person because I get a bagel & coffee and stay for 3 hours? The funny thing is that I've never used their bathroom (is there one?). The coffee is so good and no one ever tells me to stop helping myself to refills. Get the Bernie's Blend!! Usually, I have to scrape half the pound of cream cheese off my bagel, but what's underneath that thick layer of goo is always a fresh, yummy hunk of bread. I've had the spinach piroshki twice and both times and the bready part was somewhat greasy and had that microwaved rubber effect, but it was worth tearing off to get to the wonderful cheesy spinachy innards. Sometimes getting a seat there is a bitch. But so is life.
author: Stumbalina b.

description: Love it.  It's shitty and cold outside, but I'm out here nonetheless.  Coffee tastes like coffee, muffins are deece.  Didn't get much else, but holler at your N-Judah line crazies milling around!
author: Michael P.

description: As an avid coffee shop semi-connoisseur, I would have to say that this cafe, although the service is good, has a few downsides that I would like to point out, maybe in the hopes that the owner is reading this or something.  First, this cafe is always packed (evidence to their sandwiches), so if you are trying to find a place to get some work done or study, this is not the place.  Second, the plus is that they have wireless internet, but not always dependable.  On several occasions I have bought coffee so that I can sit down, use the internet and get some work done, only to find out that the internet is down.  Again, I have no problem with the service, but maybe if they expand the place a little more and have dependable wireless service, and (btw) allow debit card use on purchases under $10.00...I might go there more often.
author: Micah W.

description: Kind of expensive in my opinion, and definitely not the place to go to get work done, but the food is good and fast, and you can walk to the beach with your coffee still hot.  Always crowded, and seems to be a place people go moreso to get seen, not get coffee, but it's a nice sunny spot with not many alternatives nearby for a quick grab of caffeine or calories.
author: danica d.

description: The best Coffee!!!!!!  Every time I go here the coffee is the best!!!!  Not only the coffee but the atmosphere is very San Francisco.  After you buy your coffee you can take a nice walk on the beach; what a perfect way to start your morning!
author: Jennifer M.

description: Oh my god... the sandwiches... the sandwiches!! I wake up in the middle of the night craving one of these delicious hot turkey sandwiches! What do they put on them anyway that makes them so tasty?
author: Bethany C.

description: An oasis in the middle of the dessert of sand and fog that is Ocean Beach. That poor beach would be lost without this great place. Nothing else can compare in blocks around in quality of sandwiches, coffee, and "niceness". The place to be and the end of the world (I mean, the end of the N-line).
author: Javi V.

description: Sometimes on sunny days I like walking down to the beach. The best part about it though is I know afterwards, I can relax at the JBC.   Seriously great location, great variety in what they offer and super chill  feel.
author: Tina K.

description:
oh come on its so CUTE! (At least during the week when its all locals). Pinch its rosy Irish cheeks! 
If you're crazy enough to try to get served on a weekend with all the moms, babies, grandpa's and "city" folks who rode the train out to the beach only to find fog n gale force winds what do you expect? If you know the score then you'll find yourself at ********** with the rest of us, right Charlie?
author: tigipop ..

description: Free wifi.  Monster belly-stuffing subs.  Peasant pies.  Live music on the weekend til 11.  Drink a beer w/ the old school peeps.
author: Melanie C.

description:
the coffee is good.  the sandwiches are really good.  the free wifi is good.  the atmosphere is good.

the teenage mobs and the screech of the N trains are annoying.
author: Sarah B.

description: I came here for the first time yesterday.  The boyfriend and I shared the Kelly's Cove (turkey, pesto & swiss on multi-grain bread) and a large Tsunami (ham, salami, mortadella on a french roll).  The pesto didn't look that fresh but the sandwich tasted great anyway.  I loved how they put a bunch of mixed greens in it and the Tsunami sandwich was nicely toasted.  I was pretty full after eating half of it but ended up eating the whole thing anyway because it was so good.  Would definitely come back for more =)
author: Katelynn L.

description:
i dunno.  another one of those places i find myself wondering why i keep going there.  probably because it's near, and an interesting enough place.  where else can you find surf/skaters, the homeless, business people, scholars, and various other folk each talking to only their kind? except when everybody's waiting in line, which is always.  the staff is ok i guess, they once forgot all about my friend's drink.  

they have a pretty good selection of drinks and they do them well for he most part.  they have unsweetened (and sweetened or vanilla or whatever) soy milk which i love!  it's hard to find seating which is annoying because it seems to be a place that you'd want to hang out at.  

go for the decent coffee and expect nothing else.
author: Monk R.

description:
I live in the Sunset and it's really nice to have a cool coffee shop down the street that I can hit on the way to school or work.  It always seems pretty busy here, but service is always fast and friendly, and they have a good assortment of baked goods to go with my latte which I usually order.  The atmosphere in this place is pretty nice too, and with seating outside (although usually pretty packed), it seems like a great place to hang out on a warm day with friends.

I moved to the Sunset pretty recently, but you'll be seeing me here a lot more from now on!
author: Isaac W.

description: Definately my top cafe in San Francisco... the first place I visited when I moved here from Wisconsin 5 years ago... from coffee to pints and a comfy pleather couch, what more could you as for?
author: Joy C.

description: Mmm, awesome chai and great atmosphere. Love that at one table you see an elderly couple sharing a cuppa joe and another table a group of friends are discussing the Esperanza Spalding CD. I wish I lived nearby, I'd frequent often.
author: Maricel B.

description: Java Beach is great.  I love that it is always crowded because the friendly energy is contagious and I believe that is the reason why I get a lot of homework done while I am drinking a delicious Java cappucino.  My friend Olivia W. works here and still frequents the place with her roommates.  I think it says a lot about a place whose employees actually enjoy it.  It's a nice cafe in a lovely location with great coffee and AMAZING sandwiches.  Order extra pepperocinis and jalapenos on the cold veggie on dutch crunch.  Yum.
author: Christie S.

description: So I'm giving Java Beach four stars because the people that work there are cool, they have free wi-fi and hello its right across from the ocean!  It's a laid back atmosphere a nice place to hang out for a little bit, oh and they have live music on certain nights, I'm sure which nights?  The coffee is good, the teas aren't that great but they offer some good eats, some tastier than others but overall the food decent.  Overall if your down in the area its probably one of the better places to stop and get a fast bite a cup of coffee and relax for a bit.  I might be mistaken but I think they also serve beer on tap?
author: Erin S.

description: Better than average sandwiches, free wi-fi, strong coffee. I've never had a bad experience here but be careful not to sit outside under powerlines teeming with birds.  Weekends feature the Outer Sunset Parade of Dogs.
author: Max E.

description: Other than the guy in tiny shorts barely covering his crotch asking our friend for his used coffee cup sleeve (presumably to use on his own coffee cup), Java Beach Cafe is pretty cool to hang out.  It's unpretentious, cozy, bustling with business on the weekends.  I like a place where anyone can feel welcomed and comfortable, and I guess that includes the creeps too.
author: Candice B.

description: Get the tsunami sandwich.  And a cold beer.  Minus one star because it is always foggy and cold in the outer sunset.
author: Curtis H.

description:
after getting over my inital shock that people in sf will brave the frigid waters to surf (so THATS why they sell wet suits with hoods/booties/gloves!)... it was a bit odd to see such a surfer vibe coming out of a norcal joint - or is it? should have ordered coffee, but i'd already had a latte earlier, and didn't want to induce myself to even more frequent urination, so i had an italian soda. not exactly what i was expecting, and would probably not recommend to anyone. oh well. i just ordered the wrong thing.

HOWEVER. the place is packed, it smells like HEAVEN, the pastries/food look amazing, and did i mention you can get free wifi here? such a chill, chill place - but i dunno how much hardcore studying you could get done, as it is pretty crowded and can get kinda loud. but def a fun hangout, and probably one of the easiest cafes to find parking nearby.
author: Aletheia W.

description: Great coffee, great location. Just wish the line on the weekend didn't go out the door and wrap around the corner on the sidewalk...
author: Jennie H.

description: An intimate and unpretentious coffee house that sits right over by the beach.  It does get crowded, but I tend to come in the evenings when there are plenty of seats open so i can waste time on my laptop while sipping an iced mocha.  Which means that there is FREE wifi, a rare find in the sunset, at least to my limited knowledge.  Haven't tried the pastries, they look average, but the sandwiches are quite good.  I also see plenty of people taking advantages of the beers they have on tap, something I have never seen in other coffee shops.  I'm always tempted to go for a Stella, but haven't done so yet.  One day...one day.
author: K P.

description: This place is pretty great. Even if the coffeee tasted like cardboard (it so does not) I would love them for the free wifi. The coffee is delicious (Bernie's blend, black please) the staff is usually pleasant and the prices are reasonable. It's usually busy when I've gone, but I have always managed to get a seat.
author: Rachel B.

description:
great coffee place...the latte was pretty yummy...nice place to chill and people watch, catch up with friends and free internet who could ask for more...maybe better weather, but that's not their fault...:)

if i lived closer, i would be here every day and night...
author: Christina L.

description: Great location serving serviceable subs.  I like everything about the place except fighting for a table.
author: Tim G.

description: J.B.C. you work so well as a watering hole on so many levels... You can get your 'Joe' in the "am" and you can get your 'Stella' in the "pm" or vice- versa. When I'm at J.B.C. I get the feeling I'm in a colder Venice Beach all in all - the same California...
author: swys -.

description: On the one hand, it's a fun location, the coffee's fine, and the sidewalk patio is best place in the neighborhood to sit and have a beer if you're out with your dog. On the other, the lines are long, I've never had anything off the menu that's gone past mediocre, and while there are exceptions, most of the counter staff seems to genuinely dislike dealing with customers.
author: Nick R.

description: Amazingly delicious sandwiches that are VERY filling, yummy lemon bars and inexpensive drinks. Free wi-fi. Open late. Across from the ocean. They usually have a line out the door, but it somehow goes by quick and you get your food quick too!
author: Ashley B.

description: Great place out at OB.  Good coffee - Bernie's Blend.  Free Wi-Fi. Makes for a good place to get a hot cup of joe or cold beer.
author: Rick L.

description: Best spot for liquid crack in the SFC.  Only drawback is the constant presence of SF's Finest.  Guess they too know a good thing when they see it?
author: Al K.

description:
I love this place.  I've lived right around the corner for the past 2 years and there are so many reasons this place rules.

Reason #1: The location.  It doesn't get much better than this in San Francisco.  One block from the beach, with a clear walkway across the Great Highway and a wide stretch between the dunes to make your way down to the surf.  The N line turns around here, there's a beatiful community garden with benches across the way, and there's ample outdoor seating, so there's always interesting people watching and conversation to be had.

Reason #2: Chill vibe.  My favorite time to come here is a Sunday morning.  There's always a line out the door but the service is fast and the people in line are friendly.  You've got the newspaper man standing outside selling the Chronicle - he seems to feel like he's struck gold getting paid to be outside talking to people and once said to me "I can't believe they pay me to do this."  The vibe is always laid back.

Reason #3: The food and beverages.  For such a tiny place they sure pack a lot in.  They've got a bar, full menu of hot and cold sandwiches, and great coffee.  The sandwiches are amazing and a small is enough food for a meal.  I love that I can get a pint or a pitcher and sit outside with friends on the sidewalk for hours.  

The only reason I'm not giving the place 5 stars is the layout inside.  After paying, you are immediately faced with trying to fill up your coffee with no place to rest it, while people are sitting right behind you and others are trying to squeeze by.  Most people wait for their food and coffee right there as well, right on top of people that are trying to sit and enjoy their meal.  The bathroom line also forms in this small space as well.  Then, to make it back outside you have to worm your way back through the crowd, trying to to spill your coffee or dump your food on someone's head.  Add a few rowdy kids in the mix and you've got insanity.  I wish they'd redo the layout because they could take way better advantage of the space.
author: Mr. A.

description: Dreaming of a fig bran muffin combo??? I am.  How about a beer and veggie sandwich while you sit outside in the sun watching all the hotty surfers cruise in and out??   I AM!  well, one stop shopping my people, Java Beach has it all.   I am sure all of you are asking where is this place called the "Sunset"?  Could that be some where in New Zealand?  nope, it is still part of our wonderful city, just not a cluster foo ha ha as you have in Russian Hill (which I am a fan of as well).  Java Beach located in the sunset by Ocean Beach is my little heaven so don't all rush on the N line to get there.  Sunny days and a laid back attitude are the only prerequisites you need.  See you there!
author: Casey E.

description: I've been coming here FOREVER....its a neighborhood hangout owned by someone from the same neighborhood....the decor has changed...services they offer have changed..but somethings dont.....the really great oatmeal in the morning.....a bagel sandwich custom ordered....REALLY great coffee....and just a great place to hang out....
author: Gretchen F.

description: Five Stars just because its right near the beach.  Also got a good selection of pastries and bagels.  Good place to hangout when down by Ocean Beach.  Be warned it gets crowded -- and line forms out the door!
author: Ed M.

description: Warm, Cozy, and Next to the Park...: I visited this place on my first birthday in California with a friend. We sat in the roof area, with a heater on us, enjoying hot cider and soup and sandwiches. The warm woods used in the building design is fantastic, and there is a fireplace on the first floor. Great place to meet before heading to the Park.
author: Jo S.

description: This surf shack is a cult favorite among locals. Iced coffee drinks are thebomb.com and their veggie bagel sandwiches would put Noah himself out of business. Ocean Beach's Finest fasho!
author: Kitty C.

description: I love this place.  I live across town, but enjoy going there on a Sunday morning or a day off.  Good coffee, and even serves a Jumbo, though I wouldn't recommend that much.  No free or discounted refills is a bummer, you would think with the amount of business they do they could go for that.  Also, added 55 cents(?) for debit/credit card, so plan on bringing cash.  Good sandwiches and soups, also have the full range of muffins, bagels and donuts you would expect.  This place can be busy, but most people hav e no problem sharing a table if need be (and there often is need!).  Good people and dog watching as well, as there's an outside area as well, but nothing special.  Overall, the place has some charm to it that makes up for some of the bumps in the road, and keeps me coming back!
author: Ben S.

description: The place. They have a small beer bar at the corner and belive me for 5 beer and a croissant sandwich she give me a check under $20. Can't believe this place can exist. I am going back soon.
author: Joy D.

description:
Java Beach is a great little cafe. It's pretty much the only one in the neighborhood unless you count Trouble Coffee, which makes good drinks but is little more than a stand -there's not much seating inside. Java Beach, on the other hand, has plenty of seating, but it's so popular you might find it hard to find a seat. When I lived in the Sunset, I would come here several times a week to have a cup of joe and a sandwich while I got some reading done. Very good location for that kind of activity, free wifi and all. The seating is a little uncomfortable-the couches, while clean, are old and saggy, and the large coffee table between the couches is often awkwardly placed, making it difficult to use, especially with food. For that reason I would usually sit at one of the tables (the chairs are of the restaurant-standard, non-padded kind) or better yet, the bar, with its padded high-chairs and ample counter space. That's where the condiment basket is kept, as well as the free water pitcher. The coffee is above average, and my favorite is the Columbian roast. I usually drink my coffee with milk and sugar, but the Colombian is so good I take it black to get the fullness of the flavor. It's strong without being overpowering, and doesn't have a hint of harshness about it. They even sell their beans so you can have it at home, but I don't know how that turns out because I never make coffee at home. So yes, the coffee is very good, a bit more expensive than at other cafe's in the city, but you have the option of drinking it from a mug if you're having it there, which is something I think more cafes should offer.
 The coffee is good, but the sandwiches...oh the sandwiches! Some of the best in the city. They are massive and not as expensive as you'd think. The biggest, fanciest sandwich they have- the Tsunmai, a great Italian sub with ham, mortadella and salami, served on a ten-inch Dutch crunch only costs eight dollars! I'm a big guy and I can almost never finish one in a single sitting. The BBQ chicken is another great option, different from most other sandwiches you've probably had. Order it with cheddar.
 Java Beach is one of the best lunch options in the neighborhood, plus their hours are LOOOONG. They open at 5:30 am and don't close until 11pm, so you don't need to worry about feeling guilty for coming in late. The service is good too, sometimes a little curt when they're very busy, but when it's slow they smile at you and compliment your outfit. Their kitchen staff is speedy-even at busy times I've rarely had to wait longer than 15 minuets for my sandwich, and at down times they'll bring it straight to your table.
 Location wise the place has some nice surrounding scenery. It's right next to the beach, and there's a little garden plot on a traffic island nearby. It is at the end of Judah, and the N-trains have their roundabout there, so it can get rather noisy. In the mornings you'll see Muni drivers come in for coffee. One of my favorite experiences here was coming in at 6am in winter, when the sun wasn't up yet. I bought a cup and went out to the beach, watching the full moon over the ocean. It was beautiful.
 Java Beach: Great food, good coffee, good service, good location, good enough seating. Overall this place is pretty bomb and highly recommended, especially given that they don't have any competition in the area-they could've just banked on that and not tried to go for quality. The fact that they try hard when they don't have to gives them extra marks in my book. However, there is one VERY MAJOR FLAW with Java Beach that keeps it from getting five stars from me-no discounts on refills. None. You pay full price for every cup of coffee, even if you're using a mug. There is simply no excuse for this. Every other cafe I've been to gives you a discount on refills. The fact that Java beach charges full price for every cup is just greedy. If they get rid of this absurd practice I'll change my review, but as it stands, this unabashed gouging of customers is inexcusable.
author: Eli H.

description: Java Beach has a great vibe and atmosphere.  There's something very warm and inviting about the place - even when it's cold and foggy outside.  It's packed, so finding a place to sit can be challenging.  I haven't eaten there before so can't comment on that.  I ordered a soy latte, which was fine.  Nothing spectacular but perfectly acceptable.  I think this would be a great place to go for a beer on a warm sunny day.
author: Eric C.

description: Holy crap this place was busy this past Sunday. I think I was there around 12:00pm - line out the door is right! I think I got myself a Green Tea and my roommate, uh, something, coffee related, yeah. As I waited for the delivery of our drinks at the bar-like area, I saw some old guy bump into something on the counter and in a chain reaction, ended up bumping this coffee cup. Off the counter. Onto the floor. Crack! The entire staff was perplexed as to what happened. I tried to tell them what happened, but they were preoccupied with their own ghostly versions. A girl by the scene of the crime more patiently described to them what had occurred. Still not having it. The staff kept asking each other what happened as they maneuvered around the broken ceramic pieces. The girl gave a second attempt, bless her soul, and described the old man that had bumped it , who then quietly made an exit, as though he was guilty of some crime. I think they might have listened to her that time. 3rd time's a charm. Maybe. Just maybe.
author: Ken L.

description:
Java Beach is - by far - the best, most laid back, unpretentious  coffeehouse in the City.  Not only do they have awesome coffee and espresso drinks - but the staff won't look at you like you're crazy if you order a mocha or a chai (which happened to me at several of the well know "coffee snob" places around the city).  
People are moaning about Java Beach's prices - but come on!  They are far cheaper than Blue Bottle and Four Barrel AND all of their coffee is fair trade, sustainable and/or organic!  The owner - Pat - actually just came back from Guatemala where he met with the actual coffee growers!  How cool is that?  As an aside, they are also the ONLY cafe I have every seen that has agave sweetener.  Kudos to Java Beach! 
Java Beach is the ultimate "mom and pop" business - the the only drawback to that is they have not gotten the marketing hype that their contemporaries have (such as Blue Barrel, Four Barrel and Ritual) - so they get underestimated.  The quality at Java Beach is top-notch.  AND, in addition to great coffee - they also have great food.  What more could you ask for?
author: L M.

description:
TSUNAMI WARNING!!!!!

yeah i said it, the tsunami (along with all the tasty subs at Java) puts the sand(y) in Java Beach. With delicious crispy bread and all the tasty trimmings that come on a classic Italian sub, these sandwiches are among the leaders in the SF sandwich landscape.  My strong recommendation is to throw some Jalapenos on there as well.  I've been eating these subs for quite some time and they are very consistent and always filling and delicious.  Other favorites are turkey and avo, veggie and the chix salad sandos.

While I'm  a huge huge fan of the sandwiches (used to drive all the way from Potrero to get my fix) the salads, pastries, coffee, BEER, soups and especially new espresso roasts are outstanding.

All of this packaged with fast and friendly service, down home patrons and warm ambiance make Java Beach on Judah (or at the Zoo) a destination you'll want to go back to again and again.

don't listen to the haters...Java Beach is the real deal.
author: Michael N.

description: In an age when Starbucks seems to be taking over, the ambiance here is what a coffee shot should be.  This is a place where you can really sit back and enjoy a good cup of coffee.  The sandwiches are also high quality and unique.  You can't make sandwiches like this if you are a franchise with hundreds of locations.
author: Josh S.

description: I love this place, great food (giant sandwiches for the price), great coffee.  Bagel w/peanut butter at $2.75 is personal favorite.  Only gripe is it's gotten so popular on weekends it's tough to find a place to sit..
author: Gene T.

description: When summer rolls around (which last only two months in San Francisco) and the fog clears (when is it not overcast or foggy?) in the Sunset, I'll walk the two miles to hang out at Java Beach and people watch and work on my tan.  There's just something I like about the funky hippie beach decor.
author: Eric G.

description:
love the beer.
love the muddy water.
love the free wireless...
Go Ireland!!
author: Jill R.

description: I live right around the corner from this ultra busy coffee shop. There's usually a line out to the door on weekend mornings, but it goes by really fast. Since I'm not one to order fancy lattes or cappuchinos, I start every single morning off with a large self-serve coffee. They have 6 or 8 to choose from, I like the Dark French Roast. I've tried their bagels, scones, turkey and cheese croissants (toasted! yum!), and their bbq chicken sandwich which is seriously the bomb. It's pretty crackin' all the time, so there may be a wait for your hot food, but it's so worth it and everyone here is really nice!
author: j o.

description:
Generally, I like this place.  It has a kick-back atmosphere.  The clientele is made up a range of people from homeless to hippies to college students to yuppie snobs.  Sometimes the latter bring their tank strollers and have their kids screaming and running all over the place; however, it is not the worst I have seen.  

I generally get their drip coffee - Hazelnut is the best, I think.  I don't care for their espresso-based drinks because they do not know how to make them properly.  Go to North Beach for good espresso.  However, their coffee is labeled as organic AND fair trade, which is a big plus in my book and is one of the reason, in addition to decent speed free Wi-FI, that I keep going there.

The employees are generally decent, especially Cara (superb personality) and Justin (easy-going, cool, guy)  (these two are the best in my book and should be the first people customers come in contact with), this Latina-looking short woman (real cute looks and personality), and this other woman who is in her 30s who always thanks people for coming (very good touch).  I don't care for the two heavy-set white chicks who work there.  They don't project a friendly attitude and seem to be moody.  They should be in the back in my opinion.

The food is generally good.  The consistency of the service and the food and beverage portions is quite spotty.  Sometimes you go there and you get more, sometimes you get less.

They only accept credit cards if your purchase is over $10 so be aware of this.  They have a ATM machine in the cafe but I don't think it is worth the fees.

The cafe is located at the terminus of the N-Judah line, which makes the establishment quite accessible.

If you want peace and quiet don't come on Fridays from 7pm. They have a artist there with an amped guitar so it can be quite loud.  He sings generally well though.

Generally, this place is good.  It has some flaws.  I still go here because of the food and organic and fair trade coffee.
author: John L.

description: The coffee's strong, the sandwiches are some best I've tasted (the bbq chicken is better than an orgasm), the beer is cold, the weather is favorable,  and the soup is always fresh and piping hot. Plus, a great place to people watch. Oh, and carrot cake. THEY HAVE CARROT CAKE.
author: Ryan R.

description: Pretty decent cafe. It turns into a pile of people when its busy though.
author: Scott F.

description: I like this place; they have free trade coffee, organic coffee, hazelnut coffee; in short, a good variety. The people who work there are super nice, the location is great, near the beach, sometimes there are shows by local artists and...it can get crowded in the morning. They also serve beer and sandwiches and have internet. What do you want more?
author: Kyrsch K.

description: Love love love this place. I live in New York and whenever I'm in San Francisco I spend a morning at the beach followed by coffee and a pastry (or an amazing blondie) at Java. The staff is warm, food is great and homemade, and the vibe is so laid-back and friendly. There is nowhere else in the city with such a great atmosphere. I think prices are reasonable given that the coffee is fair trade and their staff is obviously paid well otherwise they wouldn't be so nice and accommodating.
author: Samantha S.

description: One of my favorite spots when I was in college, and it's right by the beach. A college buddy of mine showed me this place and we started hanging out here with other friends. Nothing beats a java spot by the beach. I've been hanging out here at the start of the coffee culture in SF, and before all the other java places started popping up in the city, especially the commercial chain ones (you know which ones I mean). The crowd was hip and the place looks colorful and cozy. I haven't been here for a while (pre-wifi days) so I don't know how it looks like now, hopefully still the same. But I do remember even winning a movie pass because one radio station was parked outside the coffee house. Anyway, this place brings back a lot of good memories.
author: Cindy S.

description:
This one is easy. There is no reason to go here unless you live nearby and cant find anything else. 

The layout of the shop is horrid. Even a short line ends up out the door and into the street. You cant read the menu without clogging the line hole and even after you have ordered there is hardly anywhere to stand to wait for your food. Most people (coffee or not) stand blocking the milk / sugar/stirring device/only trashcan area. So whether you are just trying to order you coffee, spice your coffee, wait for your food, eat your food, throw away trash (didnt see any recycling either) you are always in someones way. There is a dirty dish bus try blocking access to the bathroom and if you need water be ready for an adventure. First you have to scoot past the people sitting at the bar and the ones waiting for their food AND the ones waiting for the bathroom AND the ones using the bar counter for their WIFI. Finally you reach the water dispenser and have to reach over some guys new macbook to fill your tiny water cup and then hope to jeebus you dont get bumped or get shaky before you clear the airspace over his machine. Truly a design nightmare.

I live nearby and havnt found anything else yet. grrrrrr.
author: Timothy B.

description: This is our favorite coffee shop.  The chai and pastries are very good, and the women at the counter are very friendly.  My daughter and I go to Ocean Beach and stop in for a treat afterwards.  The people who hang out here are pretty diverse and mellow and you can often listen in on an interesting  conversation.  If it's really crowded, people share their table with you and it is just a warm, comfy atmosphere - like you would find in a small beach town.  We don't live near the beach, but come here to relax and hang out a few times a month.
author: M D.

description: This place was quaint and funky.  There was plenty of seating, as much as they could cram into the place, and nice outdoor tables too.  Lots of yummy-looking coffee drinks on the menu, and cake and cookies, sandwiches... my friend goes nuts for their tsunami sandwich, warm melted cheese over piles of meat, mustard, and mayo never go out of style!  I had their soup du jour, red pepper and corn chowder, and it was very tasty, and served with bread and butter.  If you're visiting Ocean Beach and want something simple to eat or drink, this little joint may fit the bill.
author: Canadian A.

description: This is my neighborhood cafe and I couldn't be happier with Java Beach.  Great for a quick breakfast and lunch or for a relaxing place to grab a beer.  I only wish they had a few stand-up heaters outside for those cold SF nights.
author: Jeremiah A.

description: Great beers on tap and the best BBQ Chicken Sandwhich! (Actually the hot veggie is amazing as well) And wifi-now that's what a call a great place to study. Go at night, and never on a weekend morning-way too packed!
author: Danni M.

description: this is my local coffee shop, im in here a few times a week and i really enjoy the coffee and the staff. the location is cool as you get a lot of the beach scene that kicks it out in front of the place, and the people that come here are super chill (for the most part). the sandwiches here are kinda pricry, but theyre really good and reeaaally big.
author: Sean M.

description:
meh...kinda pricey for a sandwich...people who work there are kinda bad with the customer service...the order/pick-up stategy is kinda poor, and allows for people to take others food...sandwiches are good but expensive...they pretty much only make any money because they are the only shop on the block...if you ever at the end of the N-line, and you refuse to pay less than $13.50 for a coffee and a medium sub..this is the place for you...freddy's on the other side of the park, or the rastahbar a few blocks east are much better..
Nik
author: Nikolai S.

description: I've been coming here for years.  Friendly and casual staff.. good coffee.. i just wish they could redesign the space so that the wall the  counter was on the north facing wall.. it would make the flow much easier for everyone.  but i love java b.  glad you guys are out there at the end of the road .. you're a lovely becon
author: Claire U.

description: Recent unemployment has brought me to this place more times than I care to say.  The free wi-fi and outdoor seating draw me out of the house. I've never eaten here but the coffee and beer is good.  The location is unbeatable.
author: Arthur K.

description: Fits very nicely into the neighborhood, in the sense that this depressing place is a little too dirty, a little too laid back and at the same time overpriced for what it is. Frankly, it's a kind of a dump and thrives mainly due to the lack of any competition nearby and the fact that the N-Judah stops right outside the door. If this place were in North Beach it would have gone out of business a long time ago. Pricing is also pretty aggressive in relation to the quality and quantity of what you get. Again, a little competition would probably change that. On top of everything else, it's THE slowest place I've ever been for coffee drinks.
author: john m.

description: Great coffee and excellent cookies.  Finding seating inside is not always easy, but you can usually find a seat outside.  Just remember to wear warm clothes...brrrrr.   My biggest complaint is that they are always running out of the hazelnut coffee!
author: Wendy A.

description: great atmosphere! very cozy with couches. an outdoor seating that overlooks the beach. vegan and gluten free pastries. free wifi. i had their chai and it hit the spot. i wanna try their sandwiches, they smelled so good! brings me back to college days.
author: Tiff C.

description: Java Beach is like no other coffee shop.  There is such a mix of people there it makes for great people watching.  The food is wonderful.  Try some of the hot subs, they are delicious.  The coffee is excellent and you can also get a beer on tap or a glass of wine.  The food is always fresh.  Try the Stacy's salad for lunch or the granola bowl for breakfast.  You can go there at any time of the day.  They are open for long hours.
author: christianne c.

description: Love it, when it is not too crowed.  Tsunami sandwich is very good.
author: Jack M.

description: Awesome bagels. Awesome coffee. Awesome banana nut muffins. God I miss this place. We used to live down the street and would go there every morning with our little dogs. This is a truly perfect local coffee place that serves beer and good company year round. Miss you guys :-(
author: Marisa M.

description: hands down, for the three hot, sunny days we get in the outer set a yr, you have to stop by this place. grab a drink, post up on the patio, and meet people.  the mass exodus of people from the inner city to the beach is always fun to watch, and the girls take off the 5 layers their used to wearing to try and get that 3 day tan going.  they have great beer, decent coffee, and good sandwiches.
author: Eddie C.

description: Located right next to the beach, this coffee shop is a mixture of three things, food, beer, and of course, coffee. On my recent travels to this establishment, I was told to try out the hot chocolate because it is a must, apparently they were telling the truth. After deciding to test out the wonderful liquid, I was amazed on how chocolately dense and thick it was. I called it, "A hot milk shake". The lady at the front counter was very nice and held a more than 15 second conversation which was nice and refreshing because I am used to so many people trying to act like an assembly line and not human. What I liked about the place was that it was a mecca for different social groups and with nice indoor seating and lighted outdoor patio, with free wi-fi, it was quite dreamy. Despite it's out of the city location, I found it to be indeed another local gem. This brought me to question... how many gems are there located in this city? I am soon to figure out, the coffee and other beverages are indeed dreamy. Once I get my job at Trader Joe's established again and my six figure income comes rolling in, expect more of these lovely reports!
author: Jon-o G.

description: i truly enjoy this place. nonchalant. chill. nobody cares about what anybody else is doing, which is a great place in my books. and they have good hoagies that don't make you feel like you are carrying a brick in your abdomen for the rest of the day.
author: Regina C.

description: Sandwiches and coffee and pastries are great. The perfect location.  I've been a regular here since they opened nearly 20 years ago.  It used to be a VERY quiet, locals only, Richmond neighbors only place, and maybe a few surfers, and stray walkers stopping in.  SF needs places like that desperately, places to be authentic and quiet without hype and crowds, but they are so hard to maintain once word spreads.  They've spruced it up inside over the years and word spread so now it's crowded all the time -- you get the 30 something crowds and the 20 something crowds (the folks who pit stop in SF for a year or two or three and then leave kind of crowds,), every weekend who have turned it into a lounge for themselves. It used to be a true authentic neighborhood place, quiet and real.  Now it's an I'm so cool I have my i-phone, my hybrid, my purposely messed up hair and slouchy clothes, and trying too hard to look "city but not too obviously" place.  Still love it for what it was originally intended to be.  You can't beat their sandwiches, and good coffee.  Mid-week, mid-day is best there.
author: Steve B.

description: nice location, small space. they always seem to be stupid busy but it's the best. block away from the beach, good coffee (unlike starbucks) and awesome sandwiches. great staff:)
author: kiki b.

description: I will be eternally grateful for the role Java played in my life--it  was my neighborhood living room  for 2 years while I was renting at the beach. I moved to 47th temporarily while concluding a long marriage, and stayed on an extra year to get my feet back under me. Java was my daily stop--either for morning coffee/papers, or at the end of the workday after stepping off the N-Judah when I just wanted a hearty cup of soup for dinner. Sometimes I'd have my kids and their friends in tow when they were home from college. Java is a great place if you find a groove there. Weekends and any lunch time can be frantic, so you need to be prepared to WAIT for food or coffee orders quite a bit, and seating can be competitive.  But there is overflow seating in the little park across the street or take your coffee and Chron down to the beach. People watching is entertaining--mix of locals, the Irish connection, surfers, sometimes assertive auto & bus-dwellers, weekend cyclists, and the omnipresent computer gazers who squat for hours over one cup of coffee. The Bernie's Blend coffee is my favorite, they make a good unsweetened chai latte, huge, fresh salads, sandwiches or just bagels. Yummy brownies too.  Counter staff are friendly,especially to the regulars---and there are a bunch of locals who show up frequently. They have music on weekends evenings, which can be really good.
author: Julie A.

description: love this place. its the center of neighborhood community, and of course you'd know that if you were a regular. the staff knows a lot of its regulars by first name, which is nice when your one of them. as a customer,  its a place to meet up with people, and also a place to meet new people. the food is yummie, i love their sandwiches...and the staff rocks, unless of course your a grumpy asshole, then why should they be nice back? i've seen it happen too many times. people come in with a chip on their shoulder....
author: SF Native M.

description: this place saved my life last weekend. after sitting in the waiting room at UCSF for 15 hours i drove down judah very lite headed to my little motel. thanh long was closed so i just parked my car and went next door to java beach. i had this roast beef sandwich on a dutch crunch and some sort of asian sauce  and it may have been one of the greatest sandwiches of all times.
author: andy j.

description: Awesome coffee shop! The service is always superb and the food is great! Their coffee is organic and their hot chocolate is great on a cold brisk morning/night. If you do get the hot chocolate, get it with whip. Every time I've been to Java Beach, there is a long line. I guess that's what I should expect from a popular coffee shop the size of about 400 square feet. I'm glad they are building a new Java Beach off of Sloat. Hopefully, it will reduce the crowd at the La Playa location. Java Beach offers outdoor seating and so you can bring your dog along. The best times to go to Java Beach are early evening/nights when the day was hot (for the Sunset . . . 70 degrees). Otherwise, it's great to check out Java Beach during the night time. There's always a crowd and it's a very welcoming hang out. I think that's the main reason why I enjoy Java Beach . . . it's a fun hang out, there's friendly people and the coffee/snacks are delicious. I guess it helps that it's only 1/2 a block away from my house. he he he
author: Manton R.

description: no thanks. if you drink from here your probably those people whos cups i see on the beach and the side walk THANKS for letting me pick up your garbage.
author: Anthony M.

description:
it's crowded (unless you go at 6:30am, which is when i'm usually there) and it's kind of expensive, yet i love this place.

i think it's because every time i'm there i feel as though i'm at some faraway outpost.  the coffee shop at the end of the universe, if you will.
author: Matthew M.

description: java beach is adorable. the staff are nice and efficient, they serve beer on tap as well as coffee, and my partner rates their sandwiches in her top ten list in the city. order up a sammy and a mocha and sink into the comfy old couches. you'll be glad you did.
author: oona m.

description: beachside cafe. i mean, they are exactly what they pretend to be. little pricey, but come on its SF. A winner all things considered. mmmm ham and cheeze
author: Delta d.

description: for me, a good feeling or memory is all it takes for me to want to keep coming back to a place.   picture this...two friends, sitting in the sun (at ocean beach!), drinking italian sodas, eating hot subs, and listenin to good reggae.  add to that this memory:  i pulled up one morning, determined to do some work, i park my car, look down, and found a wad of cash.  yup.  these are the associations i have with java beach.  although crowded at times, i cant deny the fact that most of the time when i go there something memorable happens to me.  oh yeah, and the coffee is 'aight.
author: hollie m.

description: honestly, i loove java beach. but tonight, the old lady with the grey pigtails was soo RUUUUDE. my roommate and i come and study here all the time and always buy coffee and sandwich. so we decided to settle down at our table to study for our midterm in the morning. well, they told once hey u need to buy something in order to stay here. and obviously we were going to, so we said yes we are. but come on, we are planning to stay til closing to study and wanted to wait a little until we were hungrier. so then the old lady comes and asks us again to buy something! we were literally sitting for not even ten minutes and they were already nagging on us. she said "well im gonna stand here until you buy something" --- ruuuuuude. she was like hovering over us and making us feel super uncomfortable. so, i still love the food/drinks at java beach, but i think they need to work on their attitude. i have never had that problem at java beach before. and it really changes our mind about it now.
author: Kirsten S.

description:
Because age is just a number and mine is unlisted, the number of years stated in this review will be altered! 
Before I stepped foot inside of this coffee house, I had walked and driven by for years and just assumed that it was a dirty and would surely score at the mid-80 score level (at most) with the board of health! I could never really find a reason to go inside. That is until there was a neighborhood meeting....15 years in this neighborhood (altered) and I had NO idea that this mix of people actually lived here. Okay, so the coffee was decent. It was still hard to wrap my brain around the option of how many shots (espresso...not cognac) to choose and at no extra charge. Never, and I do mean never, have I experienced that one! A sandwich is a sandwich and theirs are pretty good. Small snacks, salads, soups, quiche, tea, beer, wine etc..
Yep, it is now my favorite neighborhood stomping ground. The staff is always pleasant, even with the line out the door and the inside temperature registering about 100 degrees!
It's too bad that this place weren't larger...always crowded both inside and outside. Luckily, one can usually find space on one of the benches when all of the chairs are taken. It's just nice to have a real neighborhood spot!
The owners are two of the most generous people that you will ever meet!
author: honestly outspoken b.

description: Great coffee, great people, great ambiance, and the food is average.  Outside seating, lots of dogs out front... A nice place to read or chat with a friend and is a good people watching place as far as the sunset goes.
author: Daniel S.

description: between this one and the new one are the only places i go for coffee...  cool folks always chillin in and around them and they have good organic coffees too...  sweet spot!
author: Anthony Z.

description: There are not many places in the city that can call themselves, a bar, a cafe, and a hang out spot...Java Beach is one of them. This cafe not only has free wireless Internet but it also has pretty good food and some really laid back employees. The only downside of this place is that due to its popularity finding a seat can sometimes be difficult. Even thats not the end of the world though, for there are plenty of seats and benches outside too. If a cup of coffee or some interesting conversation is what ya need, this is the place to go.
author: Stephanie M.

description: end of the n judah line. good coffee. sandwiches getting better. [get the hot roast beef with cheese ... mmm]. surly irish staff seems to have been replaced with college kids [don't know if that's good or bad - but the service is faster]. no posers. surfers, lurkers, work from homers using free wifi, some teens and sunset moms. usually all good. outdoor seating is great when there's sun [rare]. some couches too. enjoy.
author: makaha f.

description: the tsunami is a great lunch sandwich a little pricey for a to-go type of sandwich, but i guess i pay for the convenience of it being right next to the beach!
author: morgan t.

description: I live a block away from Java beach, but I would rather drive to another cafe to get my daily cup of latte. The ladies that work there all seem to have an attitude problem, and 50% of the times I am unsatisfied with my drink, whether it is my latte or a chai for my husband. The cafe is a really nice place, and could definitely improve alongside with the attitude of the employees. I would suggest hiring an entire new crew, or investing a few hours on customer service training.  I, myself have worked at a cafe, and can sympathize with the frustration from the nagging customer, but I am not one of them, and do give a tip every time I go there, maybe I should stop tipping......
author: miyako o.

description: i live around the corner, and was looking forward to a new cafe opening in the hood...over the years, I've grown to dislike this place, to the point where i never frequent it...the best: great on a sunny day during sunset, the view is spectacular. Prices are ridiculously high, food is average to mediocre (Costco pastries...) The reason I stopped going there is I never get the coffee I ordered, if you ask for small, you'll get large, ask for "extra hot" it will be warm. Sometimes I would wait an eternity to get my order. Some of the employees are great, and others are just rude to patrons. Once, I ordered a pastry, coffee, and OJ; coffee never comes so I ask about it, and suggest that they forgot. Reply: I am sure that came out...I further: I've been standing here and you did give me the pastry & OJ, but no coffee...his reply: are you sure?..WTF, I have to argue to get the coffee i ordered & overpaid for 15 min. ago. I have countless stories like this, and this is why I stopped going there, they annoy me.
author: Deo V.

description: Their toasted sandwiches are the best in SF.   I know it's a bold statement but I am a sandwich connoisseur and I love their sandwiches.   They're toasted, spicy, and have great bread(the harder kind with flour on top) but you have to make sure to get the toasted sandwich because they do also make an untoasted one.  Their coffee is also really good and it's an overall nice place right by the beach where you could even have Guinness on tap!   I often go there and do some homework while eating and having a coffee or beer.  I would agree with a few of these other people that the employee's are not that friendly.  The parking is also horrible, it seems like every time I go there I park in the street cleaning and get a ticket or have to move my car(partially my own ignorance).  If it wasn't for the service and the parking I would have given Java by the Beach 5 stars but the food, the coffee and the establishment itself are good enough for a solid 4 stars.  Try the toasted sandwiches out!
author: Chris H.

description: this is the spot where my friends and I go to get "a big ass sandwich"  paired with a pitcher of cheap beer...on one of those rare sunny days that I'm missing so much right now!! it doesn't get any better at the beach in SF...
author: Kat L.
